urn:contentItem:4P7G-Y090-TXN5-S2VK-00000-00New `wrinkle-killers' at work in Australia1993-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3New `wrinkle-killers' at work in AustraliaDenise Ryan

AUSTRALIA now has the latest weapon in the war against wrinkles: a laser that, it is claimed, can quickly and accurately vaporise facial lines and scars.

The Ultrapulse CO2 laser, unveiled in the United States last year, supersedes traditional methods of wiping away wrinkles, such as chemical peeling or dermabrasion, a sanding of the skin with a rotating brush.

The laser had caused a sensation in the US, said the president of the International Society of Cosmetic Laser Surgeons, Larry David.

Mr David, in Melbourne this week for the society's first Australian conference, said news of the technique had spread like a forest fire among America's many aficionados of plastic surgery.

He predicted more Americans would undergo cosmetic surgery and many had already "opted to go the laser way".

Dr Greg Goodman, spokesman for the Australian College of Dermatology, said Australian dermatologists had recently obtained three Ultrapulse lasers. They had "revolutionised" the treatment of acne scars and sun damage, he said.

Two of the $200,000 laser machines are in private Melbourne clinics and the third is in Sydney.

Dr Goodman said the laser could be seen as "a miracle cure for wrinkles" but Australian dermatologists were not encouraging the "mutton dressed as lamb syndrome".

Dermabrasion involved a broad sweep over the damaged area, he said, whereas the Ultrapulse laser gave a sharp, fast beam that reacted with water, vaporising the cells it hit.

He said the treatment was less painful and cheaper than other techniques, with patients usually have a local anaesthetic.

Resurfacing a lip or removing acne scars would cost between $1500 and $2000 with dermabrasion, he said, whereas the laser cost between $1000 and $1500.

He said the laser could also replace the scalpel in surgery, bloodlessly removing skin cancers.

All laser surgery involved a slight risk of scarring or alteration of skin color, Dr Goodman said, but so far there had been no side-effects with the Ultrapulse.

urn:contentItem:51M4-J6Y1-DYG0-916C-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Dec 32010-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Dec 3

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
Dozens of rescuers killed in Israeli fire
   MEGADIM, Israel, Dec 2 AP - A bus burst into flames as it raced to an Israeli prison during a massive forest fire, killing dozens of prison guards participating in the rescue mission, officials say. It was one of the deadliest accidents in the nation's history. (ISRAEL FIRE 4th Update sent at 07:02, 640 words.)


Israel inferno kills 40, PM calls for help
   HAIFA, Israel, Dec 2 AFP - At least 40 people have been killed in Israel by a devastating fire that tore through a forest near the northern city of Haifa, prompting the country to call for international help to put out the blaze. (ISRAEL FIRE 3rd Update sent at 05:17, 652 words.)
WikiLeaks chief faces new arrest warrant
   STOCKHOLM, Dec 2 AFP - Sweden says it will issue a fresh arrest warrant for WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange as new revelations from his website's expose of US diplomatic cables saw Russia branded a "mafia state". (WIKILEAKS Update sent at 06:17, 676 words.)
WikiLeaks founder Assange loses appeal
   STOCKHOLM, Dec 2 AP/AFP - Sweden's Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a court order to detain WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for questioning over allegations of rape and sexual molestation. (WIKILEAKS ASSANGE Update sent at 23:01, 444 words.)
UK, others know Assange location: lawyer
   LONDON, Dec 2 AFP - British police and the security services of several nations know the whereabouts of Julian Assange, his lawyer said. (WIKILEAKS LAWYER sent at 22:40, 321 words.)
NASA finds 'weird life' on earth
   WASHINGTON, Dec 2 AFP - Lurking in the depths of a California lake is a bacteria that can thrive on arsenic, an explosive discovery that could expand the search for other life on earth and beyond, researchers have found. (SCI SPACE sent at 05:49, 554 words.)
  
Snow batters Europe as UK grinds to a halt
   LONDON, Dec 2 AFP - Fresh snowfalls have swept northern Europe, causing misery for travellers as airports remain closed, roads blocked and Eurostar international rail services cancelled. (EUROPE WEATHER sent at 07:29, 702 words.)
  
Venezuela floods leave thousands homeless
   CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec 2 AFP - Torrential rain continues to batter Venezuela, leaving at least 31 people dead in recent days, as the country grapples with its worst flooding in 40 years, officials say. (VENEZUELA FLOOD sent at 07:50, 431 words.)
Eight killed in I.Coast election violence
   ABIDJAN, Dec 2 AFP - Soldiers shot dead eight supporters of Ivory Coast presidential candidate Alassane Ouattara, sparking an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council to discuss the worsening crisis. (ICOAST VOTE sent at 05:35, 665 words.)
Claim Red Sea attack sharks caught
   CAIRO, Dec 2 AFP - Egyptian authorities say they have caught two sharks that mauled swimmers off a popular resort in separate attacks that a leading shark expert described as unprecedented. (EGYPT SHARK sent at 05:59, 460 words.)
Five Dutch among seven dead in Peru crash
   LIMA, Dec 2 AFP - Five Dutch tourists and two Peruvians have died in a head-on road collision between their bus and a truck in southeastern Peru close to the Bolivian border, police say. (PERU BUS sent at 07:53, 187 words.)
2010 to be among warmest years ever: UN
   CANCUN, Mexico, Dec 2 AFP - The year 2010 will be one of the warmest ever, climaxing a record-breaking decade, the UN's World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) says at global climate talks. (UN CLIMATE sent at 06:53, 687 words.)
Denmark halts Australian toxic waste
   COPENHAGEN, Dec 2 AFP - The Danish government has postponed a plan to accept a shipment of Australian toxic waste for disposal, following pressure from the its centre-left opposition. (DENMARK AUST sent at 05:06, 281 words.)
Google's photo was trespass, $US1 damages
   PITTSBURGH, Dec 2 AP - Google Inc has acknowledged that it trespassed when it took a photo of a Pittsburgh-area house for its Street View service, but will pay only $US1 in damages to a couple who sued. (US GOOGLE PHOTO sent at 08:12, 604 words.)

Fourteen victims were thought to be homeless.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>STITCHED UP OVER LOST NEEDLE</p><p>A MANHATTAN surgeon who couldn't find a needle in his patient, but sewed him up anyhow, has been found liable in a malpractice lawsuit.</p><p>In a decision made public yesterday, Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Eileen Bransten found Dr Douglas Heymann "departed from accepted standards of medical care" when he lost and left a surgical needle inside Christopher Faas after an operation in October, 2001.</p><p>THREE KILLED IN CRASH LANDING</p><p>THREE people were killed and 20 injured when an Indonesian air force plane crashed on landing in Aceh yesterday.</p><p>The CN-235 plane, carrying three civilians and 20 service personnel, had a problem with one wheel while landing at Malikulsaleh air base.</p><p>TUB RUBS WORKER UP WRONG WAY</p><p>AN EMPLOYEE was seriously injured when she became trapped in the "bathtub" of the haunted house at Japanese amusement park Namjatown.</p><p>The woman, 29, was inspecting the "bathtub", designed to open and release a ghost when a sensor detects visitors, when she got stuck under the 6cm-thick cover. A colleague found her and called an ambulance.</p><p>TOURIST STEPS ON LANDMINE</p><p>A DUTCH tourist, 27, had to have part of his leg amputated after he stepped on a landmine on a southern Croatian island, officials said yesterday.</p><p>Stek Tesse Dieder ventured into a field on the island of Vis, which was not marked as having landmines, to watch a forest fire. He stepped on the mine when stepping off the path.</p><p>BIRD FLU ALERT SPREADS</p><p>HOSPITALS across Indonesia have been put on alert to receive and treat bird flu patients, the health minister said yesterday, hours after the nation recorded its first human death from the virus.</p><p>"We have to be prepared," Siti Fadilah Supari said, adding that 44 hospitals were taking part in the campaign.</p><p>DIPLOMATS DRAGGED FROM CAR</p><p>TWO Algerian diplomats and their driver were dragged from their car by gunmen in Baghdad yesterday in the latest abductions aimed at scaring off Muslim governments supporting the US-backed Iraqi administration.</p><p>Gunmen in two cars stopped the vehicle carrying charge d'affaires Balarousi Ali and another diplomat in the Mansour district, and dragged the men from their car.</p><p>DISPUTE BLAST CLAIMS MAN, BOY</p><p>A MAN set off an explosion in a home in Odense, Denmark, today, killing himself and a five-year-old boy, and critically injuring the child's mother, police said.</p><p>"This appears to be the tragic end to a dispute in connection with an earlier relationship," Inspector Herman Overgaard said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4GK1-TCF0-015G-X2MN-00000-00<published>2005-07-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FOREIGN; Pg. 27</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bird flu fear for Australia</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By MALCOLM RITTER in New York</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AN outbreak of bird flu among migratory waterfowl in China suggests the disease - which could trigger a dangerous flu among people - may be poised to spread to India, Australia, New Zealand and eventually Europe, scientists warn.</p><p nitf:lede="true">If the migrating birds carry the H5N1 flu virus beyond its current stronghold in South-East Asia, it could devastate poultry farms and raise the risk of a deadly flu pandemic in people, experts said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"They're going to spread this . . . thing further and further across central Asia and Europe and who knows where," said Robert Webster of the St Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, and author of a report released online yesterday by the journal Nature.</p><p>Another report, released by the journal Science, said the discovery of the H5N1 infection in migrant birds at Qinghai Lake in western China "indicates that this virus has the potential to be a global threat".</p><p>The reports echo concerns voiced last week by the World Health Organisation, which urged China to step up its testing of wild geese and gulls. A WHO official estimated that the flu had killed more than 5000 wild birds in western China.</p><p>The outbreak was first detected about two months ago in bar-headed geese at China's remote saltwater lake, which is a key breeding location for migratory birds that spend winter in South-East Asia, Tibet and India.</p><p>The virus has hit that species the hardest, but also infected brown-headed gulls and great black-headed gulls.</p><p>The H5N1 virus has been entrenched in poultry in South-East Asia since 2003, and variants of it infect people who come in contact with sick chickens.</p><p>Dr Webster said the Qinghai Lake virus was genetically different from the one that had been infecting people in Vietnam, but it was a "first cousin . . . not far away at all."</p><p>That implied it has the potential for infecting people, probably by way of domestic chickens or ducks.</p><p>If a bird flu virus infected a person who also carried a human flu virus, the result could be a hybrid bug that passed easily from person to person. "That's the spark that sets off the forest fire of a global pandemic, and that's what everyone is worried about," said flu expert Dr William Schaffner of Vanderbilt University.</p><p>The Science  report comes from George F. Gao of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, with colleagues there and elsewhere in China.</p><p>In lab experiments, they found the virus killed chickens and mice.</p><p>The Nature  report is presented by Yi Guan of the University of Hong Kong with Chinese colleagues and Dr Webster, who is affiliated with the Joint Influenza Research Centre at Shantou University Medical College in Shantou, China.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CK0-TXN5-R31D-00000-00So wry and droll with the accent on France2003-12-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisMETROPOLITANPg. 11So wry and droll with the accent on FranceBernard Zuel

LLOYD COLE

Footbridge Theatre

December 12

It would not have surprised if Lloyd Cole he of the ever present stubble, the sad eyes and the half smile had sat down with a bottle of vin ordinaire and a packet of Gauloises when he walked onto the Footbridge Theatre stage.

Dressed in white shirt and black trousers, flecks of grey in his hair (but really looking not much older than when he was first here 20 years ago) there's something of the droll French raconteur and worldly philosopher-in-song about him.

He helped the image along with an opening song written some 50 years ago in France during the German occupation that features the line "and we'll come from the shadows".

Partly sung in French, it had that mix of romanticism and intellect that characterises French chanson and Cole's own career.

The song was taken up by the American-resident, British-born Cole this year as a quiet gesture of defiance of the anti-French hysteria in the US prior to the second Gulf war. But it was also a perfectly weighted opening to the evening: a setting of the tone for a show that offers nothing more than Cole, an acoustic guitar and a glass of what may have been whisky.

Barely speaking for some time, wryly smiling at the occasional comment from the room (a room thankfully where, unlike his 2000 show at the Basement, everyone could see and sit in comfort) he began in a subdued but quietly intense manner.

Are You Ready To Be Heartbroken, the title track from this year's wonderful album Music In A Foreign Language and My Other Life were ruminative, deeper than mellow and served to focus attention on Cole's deceptively casual singing style.

What appears to be not much more than a step up from talking at times has an attractive tone, a resonance that holds you to the kind of lyrics too rarely found in popular music. But just when it seemed the night was to be a candlelit evening of intimacy "I may perk up later," Cole said at one point before, with another wry smile, adding "but then again I may not" he began to shift gears gradually but consistently.

There was a Roy Orbison rhythm in one song, a gentle sway in No More Love Songs and some jaunty moments that had Cole standing and tapping away.

And then, just before ending the night with Forest Fire, Cole threw in one of those lines you know you could never get away with delivering but his characters somehow do: "You look so good when you're depressed . I love you best undressed".

How very French.

urn:contentItem:3XN3-MFB0-0045-53T0-00000-00<published>1999-10-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Part A; Page 18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CHARMING REACH FOR THE STARS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DOUGAL MACDONALD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">October Sky (PG). At Electric Shadows.</p><p nitf:lede="true">WHILE the American dream takes a variety of external forms, the common thread is simple folk striving for the seemingly unattainable.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Joe Johnson's warm and likeable film based on the book Rocket Boys (of which the film's title is an anagram) tells how Homer Hickham (Jake Gyllenhaal) escaped from the bleakness of a Virginia coal town to become one of the team at NASA, where he trained astronauts for space-shuttle missions until retiring last year.</p><p>Its events are essentially true, subject to a tad of film-maker's licence that occasionally leads to fumbles for sharp eyes to detect. But these don't detract from the comprehensive power within the drama or the total charm of its telling about the school year of 1957-58 after the advent of the first man-made object to go into earth orbit, Sputnik I.</p><p>October Sky offers an intertwining of several on-going themes  Homer's determination, inspired by what he saw, to reach for the stars (or at least, to build the wherewithal); his relationship with his mine-foreman father (Chris Cooper giving a great performance with nice restraint) whose devotion to his work shuts out any other life interest; the persistence of Freda Riley (Laura Dern), the science teacher blighted by Hodgkins Disease who used great wisdom to guide Homer and his three associates through difficulties with school management to the 1958 National Science Competition.</p><p>None of the characters uses devious or nasty means to deflect Homer from his course. Yet it is not a story of progress uncluttered by pitfalls. It comes close to disaster, when the world beyond Coalwood learns of the boys' experiments and the State Police blame one of their rockets for kindling a forest fire.</p><p>There are moments of tension, especially one wonderful passage where the boys take high-quality steel from a closed railway track then hear the whistle of an approaching freight.</p><p>But for the most part, October Sky is an agreeable, comfortable piece with a capacity to engage viewers' emotions yet avoid wringing them too hard. It was well received at the Noosa Film Festival and I enjoyed it enough then to see it a second time.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5D83-Y5P1-F0NT-H3GM-00000-00IBM unveils chip that simulates brain functions2014-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisIBM unveils chip that simulates brain functionsDon Clark - Wall Street Journal

Tech giant says it has developed a microchip that simulates functions of neurons, synapses and other features of the brain to perform calculations.

Wall Street Journal

International Business Machines Corp (IBM) is claiming a major advance in emulating the brain in silicon.

The technology company has developed a microchip that simulates functions of neurons, synapses and other features of the brain to perform calculations. IBM says the chip, a sharp break from the fundamental design used in most computers, excels at chores like recognising patterns and classifying objects while using much less electrical power than conventional hardware.

IBM's new chip is the latest in a series of efforts by the company and others to design brain-like chips as traditional chip manufacturing yields fewer dramatic breakthroughs. But its latest offering, described in a paper in the journal Science, has novel features that include its large size and the use of standard digital technology rather than esoteric materials or production processes.

Though it’s providing few details on timing, IBM says it is already talking to potential partners about ways to bring the chip to market. The company has connected multiple chips together to test potential system designs, and sees applications of the technology ranging from room-size supercomputers to floating jellyfish-shaped devices that could sense tsunamis or other aquatic conditions.

"We have huge commercial ambitions," said Dharmendra Modha, a researcher at IBM's Almaden Research Center here whose titles include chief scientist for brain-inspired computing.

Say hello to TrueNorth

The chip, dubbed TrueNorth, was built for IBM by Samsung Electronics Co. using the same manufacturing technology the South Korean company uses to make microprocessors for smartphones and other mobile devices. IBM collaborated on the underlying design with researchers at the New York City campus of Cornell University in a project that has received $53 million in funding since 2008 from the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

IBM's announcement comes as both scientists and engineers are pondering the prospect of slowing improvements of conventional microprocessors. Historically, manufacturers steadily have shrunk chip circuitry, reducing costs while improving calculating speed and reducing power consumption.

But chip manufacturers can no longer rely on traditional processes to produce dramatic improvements, particularly for scientists grappling with supercomputers that have power needs already approaching those of small cities. Radically different chip architectures like TrueNorth may help.

"Power is the fundamental constraint as we move forward," says Horst Simon, deputy director of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, a major supercomputer user. "This chip is an indication that we are really at the threshold of a fundamental change in architecture."

The new IBM chip is designed for low-power consumption. The TrueNorth chip, shown at left in blue, is being fed data by hotter chips at right in a thermal image provided by IBM.

The underlying design used in most computers and microprocessors since the 1940s—named after mathematician John von Neumann —separates components that carry out calculations from memory circuity that stores data. Bits are shuttled between those components through a conduit called a bus, with activity synchronised by an internal clock. The scheme works well for tasks like adding repeated sets of numbers, Mr. Modha says. And chips have become much faster for such jobs as manufacturers have increased the frequency of the clock's timing pulses.

But that trend also tends to boost a chip's power consumption. Moving data back and forth over a bus, meanwhile, tends to slow calculations, he said.

Brains, by contrast, are compact and particularly efficient at chores like recognizing a person's face or distinguishing one sound from another, Mr. Modha says. Cells called neurons process and transmit information that is stored nearby, connected by structures called synapses.

TrueNorth, IBM says, uses 5.4 billion transistors—four times more than a typical PC processor—to yield the equivalent of one million neurons and 256 million synapses. They are organised into 4,096 structures called "neurosynaptic cores," each able to store, process and transmit data to any other using a communications scheme called a crossbar.

The design is "event-driven," Mr. Modha says. That means that individual cores fire up only when they are needed, rather than running all the time.

This scheme makes the chips more power efficient. Where a comparable standard microprocessor draws 50 to 100 watts per square centimeter, TrueNorth draws just 20 milliwatts, or thousandths of a watt, IBM says.

In a demonstration, Mr. Modha showed how the technology used with a video camera atop a building can pick out and track people walking below. Besides daisy-chaining TrueNorth chips to make large systems, IBM expects to distribute a smaller, simpler chip for applications where space is paramount or humans can't easily go. Potential applications described by the company include ball-size rolling robots with cameras to inspect disaster sites and leaf-size sensing devices that could be scattered during a forest fire.

"It's not going to replace conventional computers," Mr. Modha says. "It is a complementary relationship."

The "neuromorphic" challenge

Other companies, including chip giants Intel Corp. and Qualcomm Inc have their own designs for what engineers call "neuromorphic" chips. Once working devices have been created, engineers face the equally daunting task of persuading programmers to learn new methods for creating useful software.

IBM has tried to address the obstacles, developing a special programming language and tools to simulate such chips. The technology "is much closer to being usable than a lot of other neuromorphic systems others have developed," says Rajit Manohar, a longtime collaborator who is professor of electrical and computer engineering at Cornell Tech.

But other experts say it is too early to identify front-runners in the field. One is Jeff Hawkins, a mobile-device pioneer and co-founder of Numenta, a start-up that has been building hardware and software based on a lengthy study of the brain.

Mr. Hawkins believes that largely two-dimensional chips like TrueNorth will give way to stacks of chips or other approaches that more closely emulate the brain's many connections. It's "a many-year process to find out what the right neural architecture is," he says.

urn:contentItem:49K3-JP30-01S8-G29D-00000-00<published>1987-05-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CLOUD SEEDING FAILS TO DAMPEN CHINA BLAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Cloud seeding fails to dampen China blaze BEIJING._ A plan to trigger artificial rain over a nine-day-old forest fire in north-east China which had killed at least 162 people and made 50,000 homeless had failed, the official New China News Agency said yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Three aircraft had been ""seeding" clouds over burning Mohe County and neighboring areas close to the Soviet border since yesterday morning but had not yet triggered rainfall, the agency said. The blaze has devastated huge areas of woodland, and engulfed at least one entire town, Xilinjizhen, since being sparked by an oil leak from a bushcutting machine on May 5. The fire was still raging out of control yesterday and the east and west flanks of the blaze, now 18 km apart, were moving together, the agency said. Earlier reports said the fire had spread to ammunition dumps in a military base in Mohe County, which borders on the Soviet Union, but there had been no loss of life. The Soviet Union is protected from the blaze by the Heilongjiang River which marks the frontier. Huge fires also erupted this month inside the Soviet Union's Lake Baikal region, 1000 km to the west of the Chinese fire, according to Soviet press reports. Official reports gave no new figures for the number of casualties in China. Earlier this week they were put at 168 dead and 300 injured but yesterday the death toll was given as 162. Another 10,000 soldiers were brought to the area yesterday, bringing their numbers to 16,000. Thousands of civilians were reported battling the blaze, which has affected 4300 sq. km of the remote wooded region, which is closed to foreigners. Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-6DD0-TXN5-S3C4-00000-00Fire speed measure under scrutiny2002-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Fire speed measure under scrutinyThe New South Wales FiresLYALL JOHNSON

CSIRO researchers have found a measure used in Australia to predict the speed of fires is extremely inaccurate.

The measure, known as a McArthur's Forest Fire Spread Table, was developed in the 1960s but researchers have found the "extreme" fire readings, based on information from moderate fire conditions, underestimate fire speeds by up to three times.

It uses data such as rainfall, the degree of drought, humidity, air temperature and wind speed to give a public fire danger rating such as "high", "moderate" or "extreme".

Together with information about available fuels, it is used by firefighters to predict the behaviour of a fire.

But researchers, led by Jim Gould of the CSIRO's Bushfire Behaviour and Management Department in Canberra, found the research on which the meter was based did not take into account all the fuel parameters, such as when a fire last went through the area and the structure of the fuel.

"It works quite well on the lower intensity fires, which is what it was developed for, but with certain (extreme) weather conditions it can be out by a factor of three times or more," Mr Gould said.

Preliminary findings by the CSIRO's Project Vesta were passed on to fire authorities 18months ago and have been used since then as the basis for training and fire fighting techniques.

The findings are being used by firefighters in New South Wales to battle the fires.

Noreen Krusel, manager of the Victorian CFA's Natural Environment Section, said the CSIRO research was invaluable in improving safety for firefighters and the community.

But she denied the old measure had contributed to firefighters being put at unnecessary risk, or been injured or killed.

Dr Krusel said there is no evidence to suggest it was the sole contributor to incidents.

"You only have to look at the results of inquiries which show that there are complex reasons and an array of circumstances involved," she said.

Mr Gould said that despite its deficiencies in measuring extreme fire behaviour, the fire danger meter still worked well as a public fire danger index.

Mr Gould's team is developing a more accurate measure to replace the McArthur table. It is expected to be available within the next two years.

As well as developing a new national fire prediction system, the CSIRO team will research the effect local and regional landscapes have on bushfires.

Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fires threaten G-G's house</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FLAMES came within 200m of the Governor-General's residence in Canberra yesterday, as wild bushfires threatened the national capital.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fire crews were on guard around Peter Hollingworth's residence Yarralumla, but it was out of immediate danger last night.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A caravan park was evacuated and the National Zoo and Aquarium was also under threat last night, as</p><p nitf:lede="true">several fires were fanned by high winds and hot, dry conditions.</p><p>Authorities would not comment about whether the fires were sparked by arsonists but said a total fire ban was in place.</p><p> Electricity in parts of Canberra was cut, main roads closed and thousands of residents evacuated when bushfires spread across Canberra.</p><p> Authorities were last night unsure how many fires were burning, with winds of up to 60km/h fanning fires across the capital's fringes.</p><p> Two federal government helicopters were deployed to waterbomb fires as police appealed for people to stay indoors and wet down fences and gutters.</p><p>NSW fire units were called in to aid 36 ACT brigades battling to contain the fires.</p><p> They were being supported by ambulance, Australian Federal Police units, and aircraft.</p><p> Flames from the original Stromlo Forest fire spread rapidly mid-afternoon, taking the fire within 200m of Yarralumla.</p><p> A house at a riding school near Yarralumla was partly damaged and horses were evacuated.</p><p> Paramedics, ambulances and the AFP were also on hand, ACT Emergency Services operation manager David Foot said.</p><p> "It's fairly serious at the moment but everyone is pitching in to see that it doesn't get out of hand," Mr Foot said.</p><p> The Governor-General and his family were safe inside Government House but stood ready to evacuate.</p><p> Dr Hollingworth's personal secretary, Martin Bonsey, said fire crews were in the grounds and the road into the property was closed, with fears that the fire could spread to pine trees on its western edge.</p><p> "We'll be watching it in confidence that the emergency services will keep us nice and secure," Mr Bonsey said. "And if worst comes to worst, we'll hop in the lake."</p><p> More than 50 fires are also burning in NSW with several properties under threat in the Cessnock and Blue Mountains.</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Services Commissioner Phil Koperberg said at least 10 new blazes had erupted during the day.</p><p> The greatest threat to property was in the state's north where about six fires were burning out of control, Mr Koperberg said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459R-81S0-0197-X44D-00000-00<published>1999-06-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>GURU HAS THE WOOD ON FOOTY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">NATIONAL public relations guru Noel Turnbull has fuelled the forest</p><p nitf:lede="true"> fire raging around tree-loving Eagles coach Mick Malthouse, saying</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "it's possible a footy team causes more environmental damage than a</p><p nitf:lede="true"> forester".</p><p nitf:lede="true"> On a one-day Perth visit, Melbourne-based Mr Turnbull _ who confessed</p><p nitf:lede="true"> to knowing nothing about football _ suggested a "cycle analysis" of</p><p nitf:lede="true"> footy teams.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "Football teams fly across Australia maybe 40 or 50 times a year,"</p><p nitf:lede="true"> he said.</p><p>"What do those jet flights do for ozone depletion and its greenhouse</p><p> implications?</p><p> "How much fertiliser on footy grounds finds its way into our</p><p> waterways?</p><p> "How many footy grounds are water-irrigated? Water is still our most</p><p> precious commodity.</p><p> "What of all the rubbish dumped weekly by footy fans?"</p><p> Mr Turnbull, chairman of public relations giant Turnbull Porter</p><p> Novelli, is former PR head of Victoria's Environmental Protection</p><p> Authority and a former spokesman for Tasmania's forest industry.</p><p> In Perth for a board meeting, he addressed the WA branch of the Public</p><p> Relations Institute of Australia on Forests, Furphies, Ferals and</p><p> Ferocity.</p><p> "Unless we get beyond the forestry debate we won't get serious about</p><p> tackling the issues of soil salinity, land degradation, air and water</p><p> quality and water shortage," he said.</p><p> "They are far greater challenges for us and will be of greater</p><p> relevance to our children and grandchildren."</p><p> Mr Turnbull said being environmentally conscious was right but</p><p> Australians did not know all the facts or understand advances in</p><p> science and technology.</p><p> He said highly urbanised Australians clustered around the coastline</p><p> and hardly ever went to see the forests.</p><p> "The more urbanised we are, the more attractive is the wilderness _</p><p> it seems romantic," Mr Turnbull said.</p><p> For most people it was easier to "worry about the forests" than to</p><p> cut car use and reduce house sizes, he said.</p><p> People eased their consciences weekly, recycling newspapers, plastics</p><p> and bottles, "feeling they are doing something".</p><p> He said forests were successfully chosen as an issue by greenie</p><p> groups, which had established enormous clout and credibility in the</p><p> community _ "because forests don't touch people's lives".</p><p> Referring to Senator Dee Margetts' arrest, Mr Turnbull said</p><p> pro-loggers should avoid creating martyrs.</p><p> "Starve the issue of oxygen," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4580-89V0-0197-54S1-00000-00<published>1999-07-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Goodness, gracious, a great ball of fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CHRISTOPHER DORE * New Zealand correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">NEW Zealanders could have been forgiven yesterday for actually believing Nostradamus's 16th century prediction that the end of the world would come this month in the form of a "great king of terror" from the sky.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Hundreds of people across large tracts of the country were stunned as a massive ball of fire with a lengthy vapour trail screamed across the afternoon sky before exploding in a haze of orange and blue light and smoke.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Emergency services were sent scurrying throughout the central North Island in search of the meteorite reported to be as large as a family-size car that looked to have plummeted to earth near Napier, 300km north-east of Wellington.</p><p>One witness said she was terrified as she saw the object explode before her.</p><p> "I was absolutely trembling with fear, it was like a huge dynamite explosion but in the sky … the house shook, the ground shook, it appeared to be quite close," Jocelyn Nancarrow said yesterday.</p><p> Pilots and air traffic controllers also spotted the object as it hurtled towards the earth in a north-westerly direction just after 4pm local time.</p><p> It also was thought to initially have been tracked on radar screens, which would mean the meteor would have to be at least as large as a small vehicle.</p><p> There were other reports that a forest fire was ablaze north of Napier, started by falling debris from the meteor.</p><p> Nostradamus, the French astrologer famous for his prophecies, predicted in 1555 that the world would end in 1999 in the seventh month: "The year 1999, seven months from the sky there will come a great king of terror."</p><p> But John Field, from New Zealand's national observatory in Wellington, told The Australian there was little cause for concern. He said the meteor was likely to consist of rock and other volatile material and be the size of a basketball.</p><p> "Something that size, if it hits someone on the head it would be pretty messy but if it hit a building it would just do a small amount of damage … it wouldn't be making big holes like in Armageddon or anything like that," he said.</p><p> As for Nostradamus, Mr Field added: "In an infinite universe anything is possible but I find it highly improbable … that a meteor will wipe out the Earth."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:459J-DY60-0197-T2BJ-00000-00<published>1996-05-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fire rages in Rocky Mountains FIREFIGHTERS battled yesterday to contain a raging forest fire in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains that had scorched 4450 hectares of Colorado's Pike National Forest, officials said. Up to six homes were destroyed in the Buffalo Creek area about 48 kms southwest of Denver.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Experts to confer on JFK's death A "WHO killed President Kennedy?" conference is to be held in Britain to explore the latest evidence being released from US government archives on the assassination that shook the world on November 22, 1963. Top experts on John F Kennedy's death are to gather in a hotel in the northern English town of Liverpool at the end of July.</p><p>Iraq to respond on oil sales IRAQ is expected to respond today to a tentative deal under which it could resume oil sales, but Baghdad's chief negotiator said the two sides were still in consultations over details of the deal. An agreement would allow Iraq to sell oil for the first time since strict international sanctions were imposed in 1990.</p><p>Lost royal papers recovered POLICE documents including maps and security information about the English rural homes of the Prince of Wales and Princess Royal were lost by an officer involved in royal protection duties, according to a report. The officer left the folder on his car roof before driving off, said The Sun newspaper. A passer-by spotted them and handed them to the newspaper, which said it had since returned them to the police.</p><p>It quoted the unnamed finder as saying: "If the documents had fallen into the hands of terrorists, all of their Christmases would have come at once." Oxygen cylinders clue to air crash PIECES of two oxygen cylinders carried in the cargo hold of ValuJet Flight 592 were found imbedded in a spare tyre carried as cargo, strengthening suspicion there was a fire or explosion during the flight, a federal investigator said. The plane carried 136 of the oxygen generating canisters in its cargo hold, more than twice as many as previously thought. The ValuJet DC-9 plunged into the FloridaEverglades on May 11.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P8S-8S20-TX53-B4G7-00000-00Hundreds die in heatwave2007-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 19

AFP

Hundreds die in heatwaveITALY Rome, Wednesday

SOUTHEASTERN Europe was a tinderbox today in the grip of an unrelenting heatwave that has claimed hundreds of lives as wildfires swept southern Italy and bit into a national park in Slovakia.

Southern Italy is sweltering under a heatwave that has brought temperatures often exceeding 40 degrees Celsius.

''We've had 50 calls so far already for airborne intervention against fires,'' public safety official Luca Spoletini said.

''The situation is similar to that of the past few days, with most of the fires burning in the centre and south of the country. The worst situations are in Sicily and Calabria,'' he said.

In Apulia yesterday, two people were burned alive in their car near the Adriatic coastal town of Peschici, while on Monday a pilot died when his Canadair crashed while he was fighting a fire in Abruzzo.

''The alert remains high across the country,'' fire services spokesman Luca Cari said. ''We have doubled the personnel rotations to ensure a stronger presence . . . and we have transferred personnel from the north of the country to the south to help us.''

In Slovakia a lightning strike sparked a huge forest fire on Sunday that was still raging across about 10 hectares of the Slovakian Paradise national park in the east of the country.

Meanwhile, Greek authorities were holding emergency meetings on one of the hottest days of the year as the risk of fire remained high and the death toll from the ongoing heatwave rose to four.

Three elderly Greeks were reported to have died from heat-related causes on the Ionian island of Corfu overnight, in addition to a 75-year-old man who died there on Monday.

With temperatures set to hit 45 degrees Celsius in parts of the country, Greeks were warned to stay indoors and help conserve electricity to prevent power outages.

''Until (Wednesday evening) when the heatwave passes, we ask for restraint,'' Interior Minister Prokopis Pavlopoulos said, adding: ''We don't need to have the air-conditioning on all day long.''

The heatwave caused a spike in smog pollution in Athens, with ozone levels above emergency limits in several parts, prompting the government to urge motorists to avoid the city centre.

The fire department said 99 blazes had broken out around Greece since Tuesday, added to hundreds of fires that have burned thousands of hectares of forest and agricultural land since temperatures began rising in June.

Five fires were raging on Wednesday in the northern regions of Ioannina, Kastoria and Kozani, in the southern Peloponnese peninsula and on the Saronic island of Hydra.

The situation was expected to improve tomorrow, with temperatures dropping a couple of degrees.

Hungary, where up to 500 people may have died last week from heat-related causes, enjoyed a significant drop in temperatures overnight with the welcome arrival of a cool front.

Highs for today were not expected to exceed 29 degrees Celsius, down from nearly 40 Celsius yesterday.

A third degree heat alert -- the highest ever applied in the country before last week -- ended yesterday.

On the western edge of Europe, even without a heatwave Portuguese firefighters are battling blazes near Abrantes, about 100km north of Lisbon, and in the Caldeirao mountains in the south.

urn:contentItem:7VNK-S5B1-2RG7-20S8-00000-00CFA 'unaware' of Kilmore fire forecasts2009-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisCFA 'unaware' of Kilmore fire forecastsSamantha Donovan for PM, Jane Cowan and staff

The head of Victoria's Country Fire Authority (CFA) has revealed he did not know fire experts had plotted the path of a bushfire that killed more than 100 people on Black Saturday.

Russell Rees has been giving evidence in Melbourne on the first day of the Royal Commission into the statewide bushfires on February 7 that killed 173 Victorians.

He says he was unaware there were fire behaviour specialists predicting how the fires would move, even though they were working in the same building as he was.

Mr Rees says he never saw maps predicting before 2:00pm on Black Saturday how the Kilmore East fire, north-east of Melbourne, would spread later in the day.

Counsel assisting the commission, Jack Rush QC, suggested to Mr Rees that maps had been prepared showing the likely progress of the fire hours before the community was warned.

"As a layman Mr Rees, I look at that map at 16:00 - why wouldn't a warning be given to Kinglake at 16:00?" Mr Rush asked.

"The warning was given, as I suspect you know, at around 17:55 for Kinglake; that's the urgent threat official warning," Mr Rees replied.

"Every effort was made and hindsight is a wonderful thing as we all know, but people were making efforts to warn the communities, including the community of Kinglake, and in realising the whole state and the issues that pertained to the risks to the whole state at the time."

What is known is the forest fire danger index was almost off the charts on Black Saturday, with an almost unprecedented reading of 328.

Mr Rees was asked why that figure was not communicated to the public.

"To understand those figures, as in the numerical numbers of the fire danger indices, you need to understand what they mean," he said.

"So there needs to be an educative process.

"And the language of low, moderate to extreme, high extreme, is the language that's considered best to explain that scenario."

'Policy of advice'

Mr Rush observed the CFA has the statutory responsibility for declaring days of total fire ban.

But as Mr Rees told the commission, that responsibility does not extend to the issuing of warnings.

"CFA seeks to give information but it depends on the public understanding of that information and taking that information in," he said.

"Does the CFA warn or does it provide information?" Mr Rush asked.

"The CFA's policy is that it gives advice to the community before and during fires," Mr Rees said.

"If one wants to interpret that advice as a warning I don't shy away from the language warning but there is much more in what CFA is striving to do than simply to warn."

Mr Rees told the commission that while the official urgent threat message for Kinglake was issued at 5:55pm, a CFA officer had spoken on ABC Radio an hour earlier warning communities about the projected fire paths.

"The official warnings clearly were very, very close to the actual events," he said.

"In other words, the time frames are very, very tight in the getting of information and the issuing of warnings."

He said members of the public also had a responsibility to obtain as much information as possible to develop their own fire plan.

Mr Rees was excused from the witness box late today but it is expected he will be called to give evidence several times during the commission's hearings.

His counterpart at the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment, Ewan Waller, was the next witness called and he will resume his testimony on Tuesday morning.

urn:contentItem:4P0F-DRD0-TX5J-M2KJ-00000-00Bush relic shock find2007-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 71Bush relic shock findGill Vowles

A DELIBERATELY lit forest fire has uncovered previously unknown archeological sites in Tasmania's North-West.

The sites were discovered by Forestry Tasmania firefighters after the blaze swept through the Warrawee Forest Reserve near Latrobe in January.

Now Forestry Tasmania archeologist and community liaison officer Jane Becker is hoping the public can help identify the newly revealed structures that relate to the area's prolific oil-shale mining operations at the turn of last century.

Mrs Becker said although Forestry Tasmania had documented several old shale-mining sites in the area, the fire had given new insights into the extent of the remains.

''Over the years, we have found remains of brick walls and kilns in the forest reserve, along with some open shafts and adits,'' Mrs Becker said.

''But the fire has uncovered a hand-cut mine shaft which we believe is about two kilometres long and the remains of several buildings.''

Mrs Becker said one of the most interesting finds was a huge, round building with two doors and no windows.

''We believe it was probably a powder magazine but we are keen to find out how it related to the shale-mining operations,'' she said.

Although the mine, once one of Latrobe's biggest industries, had been operating until the 1940s, it was proving difficult to find the stories behind the archeological sites.

''The first shale works were opened in 1911 and they operated under successive owners until the early 1940s, so there should still be people around who remember them,'' Mrs Becker said.

The oil extracted from the shale was of extremely high quality and during the life of the mine 1,136,500 litres were produced.

However, the extraction process ultimately proved to be uneconomical.

''At one stage, the company was in negotiations with the navy to provide it with diesel, which was going to be directly piped to the Devonport port,'' Mrs Becker said.

''The deal was going to be the industry's saviour but it didn't eventuate, again because of economics.

''Plans to use the oil to produce paraffin, napthalene and bitumen also failed, although a test strip of bitumen laid in Latrobe's Stewart St was satisfactory.''

Mrs Becker said Forestry Tasmania eventually hoped to be able to open the shale-mining archeological sites to the public.

''The sites are unique because shale mining is so rare, there is nothing else like it in Tasmania so we would love to open it up to the public,'' she said.

''At the moment, we are still trying to make sense of what's here and develop some interpretation.

''One of the problems is that there are so many layers of development and trying to put them into chronological order is difficult.

''However, we are hoping to use the existing tramway to establish an interpretative walking track incorporating the major features of the mining operation and linking them to community stories.

''Already, we have gathered stories of children sneaking on to the site at weekends and using the rail carts to roll down the hill into the river.

''We have also been told about one mine manager using the oil to fuel his motorbike, which everyone recognised because of the horrible smell.

''But we want to gather a lot more stories and piece together the use and development of the remaining sites and relics.''

Mrs Becker can be contacted on (03) 6424 8388.

urn:contentItem:4P2J-J420-TWT9-22RX-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 19:00 June 262007-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 19:00 June 26ANGELES June 26

  In fairytales, midnight is the witching hour. Elaborate coaches turn back into pumpkins, proud white steeds become mice once more, and princesses revert to their lives as oppressed domestic servants. No so for Paris Hilton, who emerged just after midnight, having completed her transition from a Celebrity Cinderella to jailbird - and back again. (US HILTON SCENE (Pix available) sent at 18:40, 453 words.)


SEOUL, June 26 AFP - UN inspectors arrived in North Korea today for the first time in nearly five years, signalling a dramatic upturn in the pace of international efforts to halt the communist state's nuclear programs. (NUCLEAR KOREA Nightlead sent at 16:57, 668 words.)
JERUSALEM, June 26 Reuters - Middle East mediators held talks today that could clear the way for the appointment of Tony Blair as their envoy to try to revive peace prospects after Hamas seized control of the Gaza Strip. (MIDEAST Nightlead sent at 18:33, 565 words.)
SHEFFIELD, June 26 Reuters - Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes in northern England today as officials warned a dam could collapse following severe flooding that has killed three people. (UK FLOODS Nightlead sent at 16:49, 500 words.)
AUCKLAND, June 26 AAP - Fiji's military government has deported the Australian lawyer of a civil rights campaigner, who is seeking a court order to stop the military from harassing her. (FIJI AUST sent at 17:10, 438 words. Nightlead to come, with interview with ejected lawyer.)
JAKARTA, June 26 Reuters - Parliamentary elections in East Timor at the weekend should be largely peaceful and fair despite some tensions in the run-up, the UN envoy to the young nation said today. (TIMOR KHARE sent at 17:25, 313 words.)
JAKARTA, June 26 AFP - East Timor's top UN official warns it will take months to resolve the refugee crisis in the troubled nation, where an estimated 10 per cent of the population remain in camps. (TIMOR KHARE REFUGEES, sent 18:44, 308 words.)
JAKARTA, June 26 AAP - Former East Timor Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri says nothing has changed since he resigned from the job a year ago so others could try to resolve the nation's political and social crises. (TIMOR ALKATIRI sent at 16:10, 629 words.)
KAMPOT, Cambodia, June 26 AFP - Heavy rains were hindering thousands of rescuers scouring dense forests in southern Cambodia today for a plane believed to have crashed yesterday with 22 people aboard. (CAMBODIA PLANE Nightlead sent at 13:52, 552 words.)
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 AFP - Firefighters tackled a ferocious forest fire near California's Lake Tahoe today that destroyed up to 220 homes and forced the evacuation of 1,000 people. (US CALIFORNIA Nightlead sent at 13:46, 574 words.)
MANILA, June 26 Reuters - At least nine people were killed and dozens injured when Philippine security forces clashed with dozens of slum dwellers resisting the tearing down of their homes in a northern province, a police commander said today. (PHIL SQUATTERS, sent 15:56, 212 words.)
LOS ANGELES, June 26 AAP - Tiger Woods has released the first photos of his baby daughter Sam Alexis Woods, a little over a week after she was born. (US WOODS (with pix) sent at 16:31, 152 words.)
CHENNAI, India, June 26 AFP - A husband and wife doctor team in southern Indian were charged today with attempted murder for encouraging their schoolboy son to a carry out a caesarean section, police said. (INDIA CAESAREAN Nightlead, sent 16:10, 262 words.)

urn:contentItem:49N1-RK10-01S8-D174-00000-00<published>1991-10-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ARMY CLOSES IN : Serbs near Zagreb after mortar blitz</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Croatia declared independence in June.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Yugoslav army has increasingly sided with ethnic Serbs, who refuse to be a part of an independent Croatia. Together they have seized about one-third of the breakaway republic.</p><p>The latest battlefield action follows Serbia's consolidation of political control yesterday over the remainder of Yugoslavia.</p><p> The Croatian chairman of the federal presidency, Mr Stipe Mesic, said yesterday's takeover of the almost defunct federal parliament was a Serbian-organised coup.</p><p> But Mr Kadijevic said on Belgrade television that the army only wanted "to establish control in crisis areas, protect the Serbian population from genocide and free army personnel and members of their families under blockade in Croatia".</p><p> The army, which launched a major assault against Croatia this week, bombarded areas around historic Dubrovnik, starting a forest fire.</p><p> The Borba newspaper in Belgrade said 26 federal soldiers had died in three days of fighting.</p><p> Zagreb radio reported hundreds of women and children fled the village of Slano, near Dubrovnik, after a fierce mortar attack.</p><p> Zagreb television reported last night that Croatian forces had been pushed back to within 32 kilometres of Zagreb, after losing several villages to Yugoslav fighters.</p><p> Serb rebels and federal troops were advancing northward along a wide front in the Banija region, encountering little resistance from retreating Croat troops, according to Belgrade Radio.</p><p> Western military attaches in Belgrade said they doubted Croatian resistance could hold up longer than 10 days in the face of intense attacks that began on Tuesday.</p><p>Croatian forces have arrested Bishop Lukijan, the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church in the embattled region of Slavonia, and several other clergymen, according to the Patriarchate in Belgrade.</p><p> The Orthodox Serbs and Roman Catholic Croats share a language but have been rivals for centuries and enemies during World War II, when fascist Croats killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs and Serbs retaliated on a smaller scale.</p><p>AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5CGR-XBX1-F0J6-J1R4-00000-00anatomy of an affair2014-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisSUNDAY LIFEPg. 28anatomy of an affairfamilyDanielle Colley

Know someone who has cheated on their partner? Of course you do, writes Danielle Colley - it's biological.

Infidelity. The word conjures images of smoky bars, furtive glances and lipstick on collars. But when, according to research from Rutgers University in the US, 30 per cent of men and 25 per cent of women are likely to stray at some time in their lives, you can bet that philandering takes on every guise imaginable.

Possible outcomes of straying from a partner range from guilt to catastrophe. But, regardless of the consequences, evidence of affairs has been discovered in every single culture across the globe, even in those with severe penalties such as stoning or beheading.

Although humans are geared towards coupling, we are capable of loving one person deeply while also desiring or even loving another. New York-based biological anthropologist Dr Helen Fisher has been researching love since 1975 and has unravelled some of the mysteries behind human relationships and what happens in the brain during the various stages of the love cycle.

She says humans have evolved three distinctive brain systems for mating and reproduction: lust or the sex drive, linked with testosterone in both men and women; romantic love, linked with the dopamine system; and attachment, linked with the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin.

"The bottom line is, you can feel the sex drive for all kinds of people who you're not in love with," Fisher says. "And you can feel deep attachment for one person while having intense feelings of romantic love for someone else. The brain is very well built to do both."

Jess*, 36, had been in a relationship for two years when she found her brain doing both. She had been feeling disconnected from her partner when he brought a male friend home to help with renovations. Fireworks sparked for Jess, escalating into a forest fire; the charged atmosphere took over her thoughts.

"My skin felt electric every time he accidentally brushed against me," she says. "In his presence, my heart would beat faster, my breathing was shallower."

MRI scans of the brains of people in love performed by Fisher reveal that dopamine levels present are similar to those after taking cocaine. The physical reaction described by Jess is typical of infatuation and love; it is hard to quell these feelings because the reptilian brain doesn't care if you are available or not.

Jess did not act upon these desires, but they made life awkward when she became consumed by her unrequited feelings and they became obvious to all around her.

"As human beings, we will fantasise about people outside of our current relationship many times in our lives because biology is against us," Jess says.

"In my opinion, we are genetically programmed to form attachments to people, procreate and move on to the next person so that the gene pool is strengthened. However, we have to manage those biological urges within the social construct of monogamy - and that is where it gets difficult."

This is a theory shared by Fisher

after researching 62 cultures around the world. Although everlasting love is entirely possible, she set out to get to the bottom of the seven-year itch - only to ascertain it is closer to a four-year itch.

"In hunting and gathering societies, it takes a man and a woman about four years to raise a child through infancy," she says. "The natural birth spacing in these societies was about four years. My hypothesis is that we evolved a drive to fall in love, form a pair bond and stay together at least long enough to raise a child through infancy."

It was during this infant phase that Liza* found herself drowning at sea. After endless days isolated as the stay-at-home mum of twin babies, she created a clandestine Twitter account.

"I stumbled upon someone online," she says, "and it was the single most intense connection with another human being that I had ever experienced. I fell madly and deeply in love with her, and she with me. She made the world fill with colour and excitement."

The fact they lived in different countries did not alleviate the pain felt by Liza's partner upon discovery of the "affair".

Interestingly, of the people Fisher studied, 60 per cent of men and 34 per cent of women said they were in happy relationships when they strayed, so not every infidelity is prefaced by unhappiness. However, the remaining adulterers may discover that things are less than shiny below the surface.

"Often, when [infidelity] happens in a relationship, there's a sense of dissatisfaction or disconnection, and the person doesn't have the skills or the wherewithal to reach out to their partner to talk about it," says relationship councillor Vivian Baruch. "It seems easier in a way to triangulate, or find a third thing or person to focus on, rather than reach out and say, 'Hey, there's something going on here.'â€†"

Sometimes, says Baruch, when a third element - a new activity, a person, a distraction - takes over, it can unbalance a relationship. "Partners will confide in, or relate more to, or spend more time and energy in this third thing or occupation than with their partner. That's a dynamic that can cause one person, or the other, or both, to feel that separation or disconnection from each other and create a likelihood for someone to step out."

Four-year itch and triangulation aside, all is not lost in the land of love longevity. Research has shown that the biggest factor in remaining deeply in love after 25 years is something termed "positive illusions". If you can maintain the ability to overlook the things you don't like about your partner, you may well crack the code and live happily ever after.

*Names have been changed.

urn:contentItem:4P13-3400-TXN5-R26N-00000-00Britain's turn to burn2003-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 60Britain's turn to burnScores evacuated as heatwave leads to raging firesBECKY BARROW, LONDON

FIRES swept across Britain yesterday as the unusually dry weather created perfect conditions for flames to spread quickly.

The Times described the multiple outbreaks as "reminiscent of Australia's bushfires".

Children were responsible for starting some blazes, which hundreds of firefighters were struggling to bring under control last night.

The fire service's job wasn't helped by the continuing dry weather and temperatures as high as 24 degrees in Scotland and 22 degrees in Hampshire. In some areas, there has been no rain for six weeks.

Police were close to declaring a "major incident" in Woking, Surrey, after a fire covering the size of 1000 football pitches continued to spread quickly across a common.

Dozens of people were evacuated from their homes as winds whipped up the blaze, which started on Thursday. About 140 firefighters were struggling to contain the flames on West End Common last night. A big concern was that the blaze has swept across firing ranges at the Ministry of Defence's Pirbright Camp, which contain unexploded ammunition.

Peter Stonebanks, a fireman, said: "At times we were forced to run away and at one point I feared for my life. We had to let it take its path because it was so quick-moving."

In Glossop, Derbyshire, a town on the edge of the Peak District National Park, people were told to stay inside because of smoke from three fires. Forty firefighters and two helicopters have been battling the fires, which are also believed to have been started by children, since Wednesday.

One blaze on Kinder Scout is under control, while the fire in Bleaklow, north-east of Glossop, is causing grave concern, said Sean Prendergast, the chief ranger.

In Wales, dozens of people were moved from their homes after a fire swept through forests in Gwent.

About 100 firefighters and three helicopter water-bombers were trying to stop a fierce moorland blaze from engulfing homes in Darvel, Ayrshire. A fire at Barrow Fell, near Keswick in the Lake District, was still burning last night as a light breeze fanning the flames made the firefighters' job nearly impossible.

There was also a large gorse fire at Fiddler's Green, near Newquay in Cornwall.

The British weather forecasting service, the Met Office, has warned people to prepare for "a big change" as the sunny weather ends over the weekend. It could even snow on higher ground in Scotland.

ILLUS: TAKE THAT : A helicopter dumps water onto a forest fire in Gwent, South Wales, where more than 100 firefighters are battling a blaze.Picture: BARRY BATCHELOR/AFP

urn:contentItem:7V2T-WR40-YB64-40D4-00000-00Get ready to flee, residents warned2009-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Get ready to flee, residents warnedAFTER THE FIRES - Extreme fire danger for Yarra, Warburton valleysPAUL AUSTIN STATE POLITICAL EDITOR with CLAY LUCAS

VICTORIA'S bushfire emergency is not over, with today and Friday looming as extremely dangerous.

People in the Warburton Valley and Yarra Valley could come under direct threat today.

Fire chiefs are warning residents of these areas that if they plan to leave rather than stay and try to defend their properties, they should leave early today.

CFA state duty officer Neil Bumpstead said residents would be most at risk after the wind change forecast for late this afternoon.

Mr Bumpstead warned that if fire did reach the Warburton Valley, people who had left should be prepared to stay away for several days.

"We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested," he said.

"Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat."

The Enoch Point area, near Gaffneys Creek and south of Eildon, was of particular concern, with winds expected to turn north and north-westerly today at speeds of between 20km/h and 30km/h.

State duty officer at the Department of Sustainability and Environment Andrew Graystone said today's forecast was also for extreme forest fire danger in the Mallee and very high forest and grassland fire danger across the state, with the exception of East Gippsland.

The CFA has declared today a day of total fire ban in the north-western, north-eastern, eastern and central districts.

Premier John Brumby urged people in fire-prone parts of the state to implement their fire survival plans.

Mr Brumby said no Victorian should need to be reminded that the state is very dry after a drought lasting many years and then the baking heat of recent weeks.

"It doesn't need much to make them (fires) run," he said.

"So for people in those threatened areas, put your fire survival plan in place - and if you're going to stay and defend, do all the things that are in the rule book."

Concerned about a rift between the CFA and the firefighters' union about how the fire services performed on Black Saturday, Mr Brumby called for an end to finger pointing.

He said Victorians should work hard to avoid a repeat of what happened after the Ash Wednesday fires of 1983, when many firefighters resigned from the CFA "because lives were lost and they thought they hadn't done enough, that they'd failed".

"That's the last thing we want in Victoria now," Mr Brumby said on 3AW before yesterday's Day of National Mourning service.

"I don't know of any firefighter who didn't do their best.

"I've met some who led hundreds of people down the mountain (at Kinglake) and saved lives.

"I've met so many who've lost their own home - their own home - while they were out trying to save someone else's.

"So the most important thing in the next few weeks is, we don't want to be in the recrimination business, saying that firefighters could have done better, or this or that.

"They did their best, and the emergency services people did their best."

Mr Brumby said the bushfires royal commission would investigate all issues, including the performance of the CFA and other emergency services and the adequacy of fuel-reduction burning policies and emergency warning systems.

"We'll let the royal commission work out what went wrong, what went right and what we need to do in the future to fix things up," he said. -- With CLAY LUCAS

AREAS AT RISK TODAY

Warburton (above), East Warburton, Reefton, Wesburn, Millgrove, Yarra Junction, Gladysdale, Powelltown, Enoch Point, Launching Place, Don Valley, Hoddles Creek, Woori Yallock, Yellingbo, Seville, Wandin, McMahons Creek

urn:contentItem:53HR-1T21-JCM0-642K-00000-00Riots behave like bushfires, says expert2011-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisRiots behave like bushfires, says expertMarianne English

Tough times, lowering of self-responsibility and a desire to join in are fuelling the UK riots, researchers say.

They add, understanding the psychology and motivation of riot participants can help cities prevent peaceful protesting from escalating to violent or destructive rioting.

The events surrounding the police's part in a British man's death catalysed riots that quickly spread in England this week. Although race tensions seem to influence the rioting, unemployment, cuts to public programs and a stale economy have factored in, too.

But how do riots' destructive and violent grasps on an area spread?

Dr Kristian Skrede Gleditsch, a professor of government at the University of Essex in the United Kingdom, says the geography of riots and how they spread seem to show certain patterns - patterns similar to those followed by wildfires.

"There's some evidence suggesting that ... the severity of riots is inversely proportional to their frequency," he says. "It's kind of like a forest fire. Most fires go out very quickly, but a few become catastrophic. Once they reach a certain magnitude, they can become self-sustaining and very hard to contain."

In the case of the England riots, Gleditsch says the situation has moved past the point where police can contain violence from spreading to new locations. He says it will be interesting to study what allows urban riots to grow to this magnitude, whether they're shaped by police strategies or other factors.

Shedding identity and responsibility

Dr Jack Levin, a professor of sociology and criminology at Northeastern University in Boston, says most rioting consists of two phases in which people's motivation to behave violently or destructively may change.

Dropping one's personal identity and responsibility and adopting those of a group's (a behaviour known as deindividuation) often happens in the first phase of rioting, he says. Usually, people are pushed to their personal limits before expressing their grievances this way.

Following the initial catalyst, and with rioting spreading, people's rationales for participating in change, too.

"It has to be recognised that economic times are pretty harsh, not only in the United States but in England. There are desperate individuals who will unfortunately go outside of the law simply because they've lost confidence in mainstream politics, see the police as the enemy of occupation, and don't see the light at the end of the economic tunnel," says Levin. "They may take advantage of a dire situation in order to accumulate certain items - such as flat screen TVs - that they otherwise might not."

According to Levin, these free-for-all bouts of looting transition into a second phase of rioting and often happen when newcomers join with individuals they already know. For example, friends showing up at a riot are probably pressured by one another to act destructively rather than acting to support the original grievance.

Though outsiders should try to understand the rationale of riot participants, Levin says riots can range from the "sublime to the ridiculous," adding that it's become trendy to riot over less serious events such as the victory or loss of a sports team.

Lowering standards

Another researcher points out the difference between violent and destructive behaviours, adding that riots are more likely to lower people's standards for themselves, regardless if they have a criminal history. Overall, vandalism and looting, which are technically property crimes, are easier for people to justify than behaving violently.

"I think the threshold to engage in their choice of [destructive] behaviours is lower," says Dr Sherry Hamby, a research associate professor of psychology at the University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee. "The main thing to understand about this group psychology is that individual psychology probably explains a small percentage of these behaviours."

Though police reports and media sources might focus on the extremes of a riot and accuse all participants of having a criminal history, the truth is existing criminals are unlikely behind this riot's genesis and progression, she says.

"The criminal element doesn't really change from week to week or month to month - they're always out there," says Hamby. "You can't usually pinpoint something like that. It's not the criminals that are getting the riots really going; they're more political events than they are criminal events."
