urn:contentItem:4J6C-XM00-TWT8-W248-00000-00Bask: Bullets and Snakes take it to the top four2006-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSBask: Bullets and Snakes take it to the top fourJames DampneyPERTH Feb 5

  Brisbane and Cairns signalled their playoff intentions with impressive wins to close the regular season, while Sydney's vice-like grip on the NBL was showing signs of coming loose.


   Since the NBL changed to its current playoff format two years ago, only one team outside the top four has managed to crack the semi-finals - No.5 Brisbane upsetting No.4 Adelaide last season.
   The top four are handsomely rewarded, with No.1 and No.2 given a bye into the semis and the third and fourth ranked sides handed home-court advantage for their knock-out quarter-final.
   But the Bullets and Taipans are keen to upset the form-guide and both carry solid form into the finals.
   Brisbane showed its depth in a 120-77 mauling of an Adelaide side sans Brett Maher (calf), with seven players scoring in double figures led by Sam Mackinnon's 22.
   That included a quiet nine-point, seven-board night from import Bobby Brannen and the absence of future Hall of Famers Derek Rucker and Lanard Copeland.
   Depth, indeed.
   The win locked up sixth and a home final against Perth on Wednesday.
   The league has been waiting all season for the Bullets to show their potential and coach Joey Wright feels he may have found the formula.
   "We definitely had to come out with that playoff mentality," he said.
   "I think the guys really did that. If you lose, you're gone and we love playing like that."
   Kings coach Brian Goorjian voiced his concerns after Cairns thrashed the three-time defending champions 107-84 last night.
   Sydney played without Jason Smith and Ian Crosswhite and has a habit of switching off leading into the playoffs.
   But the Kings have 10 days off before hosting game one of the semi-finals and Goorjian needs to lift a side that looks vulnerable without Crosswhite and Rolan Roberts.
   "We look disorganised and we look like we have a real weakness inside," Goorjian said.
   "We're going into the break with a forest fire around us. That's not the way you want to end a season."
   It's a different story for the Taipans, who have won three straight and host eighth-placed Hunter on Thursday.
   The Pirates take winning form into their second straight playoff campaign, defeating Townsville 109-104 on Wednesday.
   Wollongong ensured a top-four spot for the fourth consecutive season with a 90-89 victory over a West Sydney side which will be grateful its season has ended.
   The Pigs 'won' their first wooden-spoon in a cursed season they would do well to forget.
   The Tigers also tuned up for a tilt at the title with two wins over the improved New Zealand Breakers.
   Sydney is still the favourite with the bookies, but the general feeling around the league is this year's championship winner has to go through Melbourne.
   Perth and Hunter completed the round in a match with little bearing today.

urn:contentItem:4D9M-00R0-015G-Y1TK-00000-00<published>2004-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Huge mystery blast jolts North Korea</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SEOUL: A huge explosion rocked North Korea three days ago, reportedly leaving a mushroom cloud and a crater visible from space, but US and South Korean officials said yesterday it was unlikely to have been a nuclear weapons test.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We've got no indication that anything of the sort has happened," a US State Department official said of reports that it could have been a nuclear explosion.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We believe these reports to be completely unfounded," the official, who asked not to be named, said. "People are pretty sure it's not a mushroom cloud and not a test of any kind."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>South Korea's Yonhap news agency said the blast on Thursday in Kimhyungjik county in Ryanggang province in the northeast near the border with China appeared much stronger than a train explosion that killed at least 170 people in April.</p><p>The New York Times reported in its Sunday editions the Bush administration had received recent intelligence reports that some experts believed could indicate North Korea was preparing to conduct its first nuclear weapons test explosion.</p><p>But in Washington, US officials said there was no definitive explanation yet.</p><p>The US official said the cloud could be the result of a forest fire.</p><p>A test would alter the stakes in the North's standoff with the US over Pyongyang's atomic ambitions.</p><p>Yonhap said a mushroom cloud up to 4km in diameter was seen after the blast in an area near missile bases.</p><p>"There were indications last week of an incident in the area and we are still trying to confirm its exact nature," South Korean Defence Ministry spokesman Nam Dai-yeon said.</p><p>North Korea is believed to be developing nuclear weapons but experts say any test would have been easily detected.</p><p>John Bellini, a geophysicist at the US Geological Survey in Golden, Colorado, said his organisation had not detected an explosion large enough to be considered nuclear.</p><p>"If it was a nuclear bomb, that would have been detected by everybody in the world," he said.</p><p>He said an explosion involving a conventional bomb would have been too small to detect.</p><p>South Korean Unification Minister Chung Dong-young also played down an atomic link.</p><p>"There are some foreign media reporting such possibilities, but we are judging at the moment the explosion is unrelated to such reports," Yonhap quoted him as saying after a National Security Council meeting.</p><p>North Korea has said nothing so far about a blast, but often reports on events long after they happen.</p><p>There was no immediate reaction from North Korea's big neighbour and main ally, China.</p><p>But an official at a hospital in the Chinese city of Ji'an, on the Yalu River across from North Korea, said they had not heard of any explosion or received any injured from across the border.</p><p>Aid agencies in Pyongyang said they had not heard of an explosion.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49MJ-T8P0-01S8-G051-00000-00<published>1990-12-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>HARDY GROWERS WILL ADD COLOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JACKSON J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LIVING PAGE 2 tues Hardy growers will add color F LOWERING celosia, cockscomb and amaranthus belong to the same family and are all easy to grow. They are extremely hardy and revel in hot summer conditions, performing well in almost any garden soil in a sunny position. Celosia plants are dwarf or medium growing and are suitable for borders or beds; they are also attractive when grown in window boxes or containers. You can grow them from seedlings or seeds. Seed is easily germinated and may be sown directly into the place where they are required to bloom. Any seedlings planted too close together may be transplanted to other garden spots. Seeds of celosia, cockscomb or amaranthus may be sown all summer. Some of the popular and most colorful celosias are: Celosia Fairy Fountains, an attractive dwarf variety with bushy growth and many brightly colored plume-shaped flower heads. The mixture contains shades of yellow, cream, gold, pink and scarlet. Celosia Apricot Brandy, with colorful plumes in apricot and orange that are set off by light green leaves. Celosia Forest Fire which commands attention for its many large flower spikes of dazzlig scarlet and beautifully rich purple-black foliage. This variety is medium-tall in habit and is a good companion for other dwarf annuals such as ageratum and French marigolds. Cockscombs are just as hardy as celosias and grow best in full sun. The most beautiful strain is a dwarf called Jewel Box or Coral Gardens.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The closely packed comb remain colorful for many weeks and the mixture contains shades of cream, yellow, gold, orange, rose and scarlet. Amaranthus is an attractive plant most useful for background planting behind other colorful annuals or grown to cover fences. The brilliant beauty of amaranthus is in the colorful bracts which resemble those of a poinsettia. CELOSIA is a hardy plant to consider for summer color in the garden.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF CELOSIA GROWING IN THE GARDEN</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">QCOUML-CML9012042022P60438</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">COURIER-MAILLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49MJ-T8P0-01S8-G051-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244788</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="316"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>COURIER-MAIL</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1990 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="04" month="12" year="1990"><dateText>December 4, 1990 Tuesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="52"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:4HXJ-FF50-0045-5022-00000-00<published>2005-12-31T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Get set for a horror weekend for fires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>The Canberra Times</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Mr Maguire said fire authorities were as prepared as they could be this weekend. Tankers would be crewed, volunteer firefighters on stand-by and two helicopters on call to spot or water-bomb fires.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The ACT also had access to a fleet of firefighting aircraft from across the nation which could be deployed through the National Aerial Firefighting Centre.</p><p>"The forecast for the weekend is looking very, very harsh as far as fire conditions go," Mr Maguire said.</p><p>Mr Maguire said arson was suspected in the Yarralumla fire, because it appeared not to have happened naturally.</p><p>He was unequivocal in saying more grass fires would happen in the ACT this summer.</p><p>"The grass is long and it's very dry. We're moving into a period of summer where traditionally the winds get stronger and [there are] dry north-westerlies and high temperatures. That, combined with any source of ignition, is going to give us some fast-running grass fires." Mr Maguire said the kind of fire that might confront firefighters this weekend would not be the same as in 2003 when the January 18 firestorm killed four people and destroyed 491 homes.</p><p>"The weather conditions, I guess, in some ways are similar but the very big difference is that we don't have the forest fire loads that we had in 2003," he said.</p><p>Mr Maguire said two debriefing sessions had been held after the Yarralumla fire to further prepare firefighters for the weekend.</p><p>Firefighters were at the brickworks on Thursday in seven minutes after receiving numerous triple 0 calls but the fire was moving too quickly.</p><p>"I think [Thursday] just highlights to not only the Canberra community but to firefighters how … quickly that fire can grow and spread," he said.</p><p>"It was very unfortunate that those homes were lost. We responded initially to a fire at the rear of the brickworks, where the call came from. That fire had already moved across the bush by the time we'd arrived there and we had to redeploy into Yarralumla.</p><p>By the time we'd done that loop, both houses were actually on fire." Officers from the Fire Brigade doorknocked residents in Yarralumla to answer questions about Thursday's blaze and offer advice.</p><p>"What I would say to the community of Canberra is … [we] see properties which have long grass, that have still got their firewood stacked down by the back door and you can see the leaf material and bark that's sitting in their gutters," he said.</p><p>"Clean it out today. Don't leave it for the weekend, that just might be too late ..." More details about how to prepare for a bushfire is in Emergencies and the National Capital: A residents' guide. It was delivered to all households in October.</p><p>Additional copies are available at <url normalizedValue="http://www.esa.act.gov.au">www.esa.act.gov.au</url>, Canberra Connect shopfronts or by calling Canberra Connect on 132281.</p><p>Anyone with information on the Yarralumla fire is urged to all Crime Stoppers on 1800333000.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4D61-G8Y0-015G-W022-00000-00<published>2004-08-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 10</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>DOOM & GLOOM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">GRENADE EXPLODES IN MARKET</p><p nitf:lede="true">A GRENADE exploded at a crowded market in Assam, north-east India, today, injuring seven people just hours after two other bomb blasts left five dead and 39 wounded.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Suspected militants of the outlawed United Liberation Front of Asom hurled the grenade at the market in Tangla, Inspector General of Police Khagen Sharma said. Earlier, five people died when a passenger bus and another carrying paramilitary soldiers and their families were blown up in separate explosions.</p><p>WORKERS WASHED AWAY IN RIVER</p><p>AT LEAST 37 Indian workers were feared drowned today after their tractor-trailer was swept away as it crossed a fast-flowing river near Nepal's borders.</p><p> Rescuers have so far recovered two bodies from the Kailash river near the town of Sitarganj, Kumaun district commissioner Rakesh Sharma said.</p><p>FORESTRY STAFF CAUGHT IN FIRE</p><p>SIX forestry workers were killed yesterday while battling a forest fire in a rugged area of the southern Turkish province of Antalya.</p><p> The workers were asphyxiated by smoke as they ran away from flames fanned by the wind near Gundogmus. Their bodies have not been identified yet.</p><p>SORCERER CONJURED UP BODIES</p><p>CHINESE police have detained a "sorcerer" who killed 10 people and sold their bodies to bereaved families to cremate in the place of loved ones who were secretly buried.</p><p> Police said the 34-year-old man strangled or poisoned the 10 villagers at his home, next to a temple, in the southern province of Guangdong. Chinese tradition says burial brings peace to the dead and tombs are placed according to the laws of geomancy. But in a country of 1.3 billion people, this practice wastes scarce farmland.</p><p>ONE MILLION PEOPLE EVACUATED</p><p>TYPHOON Aere crashed into mainland China yesterday, unleashing torrential rains and prompting the evacuation of up to a million people.</p><p> The death toll climbed to 34 after a mudslide killed 15 villagers in Taiwan.</p><p>GRANDMA ATTACKED OVER EGGS</p><p>A LONG ISLAND man exploded in fury at his grandmother and tried to chop her into pieces because she fried his eggs instead of scrambling them.</p><p> Craig Daniels, 20, flew into a rage at the botched food order, first attacking the woman, 63, with a mobile phone after she called police, Nassau County Detective Lt Gregory Detwiller said.</p><p> Then, when she locked herself in a bedroom, Daniels grabbed a claw hammer with an axe attachment and began chopping through the door in a scene straight out of The Shining. Daniels was arrested when police arrived.</p><p>$80m SIGNALS END OF SMOKESCREEN</p><p>AN $80 million settlement has been reached in a US lawsuit against the operators of a Rome, Georgia, crematorium where the remains of 334 people were found strewn across the grounds.</p><p> The settlement was reached today after the start of the trial stemming from the lawsuit filed by nearly 1700 people who said their relatives' remains were mishandled.</p><p> US District Judge Harold Murphy commended both sides for the amicable agreement.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P7M-CXW0-TXN5-R38F-00000-00TOWNS IN FIRE PATH GET READY TO FLEE1990-12-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1TOWNS IN FIRE PATH GET READY TO FLEEDEBORAH CORNWALL

More than 350 fire-fighters battled to contain a major fire west of Mudgee last night as it continued to travel out of control towards two townships.

The four-day-old fire was the largest of an estimated 45 major fires around the State yesterday. It was one of four areas still under emergency control last night in a bushfire season which has already been declared by firefighters as the worst in a decade.

A spokesman for the Bush Fire Brigade, Mr Kerry Morrisey, said the Mudgee fire had already destroyed an estimated 7,000 hectares in the Rylstone Shire, fanned by a day of gusty north-westerly winds.

A massive back-burning operation five kilometres south-west of the townships of Charbon and Clandulla was expected to continue throughout the night to avert any threat to the 200 residents, although there had been no reports of property damage or injuries to date, he said.

In Victoria, a volunteer firefighter died battling the State's biggest bushfire of the summer yesterday, and the State Government pledged cash aid for its victims.

As more than 500 firemen fought to contain sections of the fire in the Strathbogie Ranges in north-eastern Victoria, the man was killed instantly when he was hit by the smouldering branch of a tree while standing on the back of a fire-fighting tanker.

North of Sydney, three major fires in the Cessnock region were still being bought under control last night, while further north another serious fire was burning on four fronts in the Parry Shire, 35 kilometres from Tamworth.

According to the Bush Fire Brigade, one fire front had already burnt through 5,000 hectares in the rugged bushland area of Moonbi, but there had been no reports of property damage.

The shire fire control officer, Mr Gerard Ryan, said the fire fronts had so far been too inaccessible for firefighters to reach, although extensive back-burning had already been conducted since the fire began last Sunday. Weather conditions allowing, he hoped the fire would burn out within the next three days.

In Sydney, where there were 18 small fires reported yesterday, the only area still causing concern last night was the city of Campbelltown.

The threat to Campbelltown remains on two fronts with fires extending across 5,000 hectares in the Wedderburn State Forest south of the city and a small fire at the Holsworthy Army base to the north-east.

While Bush Fire Services said the fires posed no immediate threat to the 1,500-strong township of Wedderburn, only half a kilometre from the forest fire, the acting Campbelltown mayor, Mr John Hennessey, launched an angry attack on the Army and the Water Board for failing to take adequate action to contain fires on their land.

The Wedderburn State Forest fire, he said, had been sparked by another fire on the Army range last week, which spread on Sunday to the Water Board catchment area between Wedderburn and Appin before travelling through to the State forest on Christmas Eve.

Mr Hennessey said the Holsworthy Army range, which was littered with unexploded ammunition, had a long history of bushfires which could have been prevented if the Army had taken sufficient precautions.

The Water Board had also been remiss for failing to provide firefighting equipment to deal with its own fires, relying once again on the volunteer firefighters from Campbelltown City Council.

"I am convinced this is just a classic case of Westie bashing," Mr Hennessey said.

"If these fires had been anywhere else you would have had Government ministers flying over the area in helicopters with the media.

"Instead, the fire has gone on for more than a week while our volunteer bushfire fighters have been left to fend for ourselves with very limited resources from the Bushfire brigades.

"There were 200 firefighters fighting in gullies on Christmas Day putting their lives at risk while the Army went onto a skeleton staff."

In Victoria, fires continued to burn out of control in inaccessible country around Mount Wombat, with firemen using heavy machinery to try to seal off the flames.

By yesterday the fire had burned more than 23,000 hectares of bush and farmland, burned down several homes and a church, and killed more than 10,000 sheep.

On Thursday, flames came within a kilometre of the small township of Strathbogie, and yesterday 50 farms in the area were counting the cost of the bushfire, which destroyed scores of farm outbuildings.

The Acting Premier, Mr Jim Kennan, announced an aid package for victims of the bushfires, to help them rebuild.

Illus: Ready to leave ... Kim Shaw loads the family rocking chair into a trailer as the fires threaten Clandulla. Picture by JACK PICONE

urn:contentItem:4V6C-3TY0-TXX1-F179-00000-00Your Say2008-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisOPEDITPg. 33Your Say

Swan's discipline is shooting blind

WAYNE Swan's reference to ``disciplined government spending'' has to be taken with more than a grain of salt (``Year of paying dearly'', December 19).

After railing against the Howard government's alleged middle-class welfare excesses, he and Kevin Rudd succeeded only in panicking the RBA

into economy-stalling interest rate hikes.

Since then, disciplined spending has featured an economic stimulus package, shooting blind rather than targeted.

While more cautious recipients will spend it on bills and paying off debt, there is evidence of splurges -- like the computer games bonanza -- which will boost only raw sales figures and technically avoid recession.

It is an irony that such spending on imported gadgets will not benefit the local economy, but ``wasting'' the windfall on alcohol and partying will.

J. Morrissey, Hawthorn

Taxi screens are a rank proposal

AS someone who has been involved in the taxi industry for 30 years, I believe if Ms Kosky and her ``expert'' advisers had done their homework, they would have established that screens in taxis do not work.

A simple trip to Sydney, where what screens that are left are hanging off their brackets, would have told them that. The only ``screens'' that work are like those in London and New York where they have expensive, custom-built taxis, which put the driver in a capsule, and passengers cannot ride in the front seat.

Let's hope Australia never gets to this stage.

Alan Jakins, Northcote

Let's take these hoons off the road

ANYTHING that places children's lives in danger is a serious problem (``Hoons put kids' lives in danger'', December 19).

Clearly, they treat our precious schoolchildren and school safety zones with callous indifference.

Fines and the impounding of cars for two days is a joke, and indeed seen as a badge of honour by young road hoons.

With more than 3000 hoon drivers apprehended this year, it is clearly a serious situation, and needs strong intervention.

It's high time that our gutless Government put some real teeth into curbing hoon driving.

Irrespective of vehicle ownership, the first offence should be six months' impounding of the offending vehicle.

Max, Melbourne

Top 50 deserves medal for optimism

ACCORDING to Jon Anderson, we are the second-greatest sports power in the world -- again (``Ando's Top 50'', December 15-19).

I wish.

The Bejing Olympics showed where our place is.

Most of the Australian names on the list would amaze most people who know sport. For example, why is Gary Ablett, representing a tribal game, supposed to be a better athlete than, for example, Brazilian volleyball player Giba, representing a game that is one of the most popular all over the world?

With due respect to all nine Australians, only Stephanie Rice and possibly Emma Snowsill deserve to be in the Top 50.

Michael Filek, Wantirna South

How will they keep us safe from fire?

OUR family is involved in the current Barmah forest debacle (``Cattle bush battle'', December 19). Our farm is bordered by the forest, on the outskirts of town.

Interestingly, in all the DSE statements on the subject, they have not addressed how or if they are going to reduce the fine-fuel fire load in the forest, which is all the community has asked for from the beginning.

Deborah Moor, Barmah

Smoke and mirrors from cattlemen

IF the small group of Barmah cattlemen really wanted to do something positive for the environment, they would cease breaking the law and keep their cows out of the Barmah forest.

Fire risk is always an issue on any public or private land, but the land manager (DSE) knows that the main fuel in these forests is leaves and twigs, which cows don't eat.

Nick Roberts, Victorian National Parks Association, Shepparton

urn:contentItem:44KP-Y210-0197-F0RG-00000-00<published>2000-11-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bittersweet but beautiful</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Noel Mengel</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MUSIC</p><p nitf:lede="true">LLOYD COLE, The Zoo, Fortitude Valley</p><p nitf:lede="true">Reviewer: Noel Mengel</p><p nitf:lede="true">YOU know times have changed when Lloyd Cole walks on for his first Brisbane concert in 15 years and tells the sold-out crowd to ring the babysitters, we could be here for a while.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The engaging Cole looks reassuringly undamaged for a man approaching 40, and the bittersweet melancholy of his tunes are standing the test of time equally well. Good songs last the distance, long after bands, hype and chart success have faded.</p><p>The English-born, Massachusetts-resident songwriter admitted he didn't mind indulging in nostalgia even if he didn't necessarily approve, and this two-set solo show demonstrated that there is plenty more to the Cole catalogue than his '80s hits with the Commotions.</p><p>Naturally, favourites like Lost Weekend and Are You Ready to be Heartbroken? were welcomed like long-lost friends, and as the clock ticked toward midnight he even delivered Forest Fire on request for a woman whose sitter could wait no longer.</p><p>Songs like Sentimental Fool showed what the masses have been missing out on in his solo years, and new tunes like The Impossible Girl are ample demonstration that there is plenty of creative fire still burning.</p><p>Cole also must have the kind of record collection you would love to spend an evening with, judging by an impeccable choice of covers which ranged from Leonard Cohen's Chelsea Hotel to Nick Cave's People Ain't No Good and Dylan's You're a Big Girl Now (dedicated to Robert Forster).</p><p>If there were quibbles they would be that two hours on stage in the Brisbane heat can be an endurance test and that the stage sound didn't carry to the back of the room.</p><p>But this toe-in-the-water tour shows there are many who still love these songs -- let's hope we don't have to wait another 15 years before he plays them for us again.</p><p>Chuck Jenkins of Icecream Hands also delivered a fine support set, with hook-laden hits-in-waiting like Spiritlevel Windowsill and Nipple demonstrating that this is one of the best songwriters to emerge in this part of the world since Neil Finn. One to look forward to: a great new tune possibly called Keeping the Cannonballs Clean, inspired by his hero Spike Milligan.</p><p>A Christmas wish: peace on Earth and more music this good on the radio.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-6CR0-TXN5-S2K4-00000-00Laugh-o-gauge barely flickers2002-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisTHE CULTUREPg. 12Laugh-o-gauge barely flickersTelevision - PREVIEWMICHAEL SHMITH

Thus My Hero

The alien force come to Earth to wreak peace and goodwill to all in the name of truth, justice and preposterous scripts has been around on television since well before George Reeves proved he wasn't Superman by shooting himself in the head. Give or take a few doses of Red or Green Kryptonite, the essential plot details remain the same.

Thus My Hero (8.30pm, ABC), a British comedy about an alien from the planet Ultron, who is living with his earthling wife and their stupendously brilliant half-alien baby in a north-west suburb of London. Men may be from Mars, women from Venus, but George Sunday, from Ultron, is out of his depth in Northolt.

So is the series. The plink-plonk, thump-thud of AutoDialogue maintains its plodding metre, accompanied by the polite laughter of the captive audience, maybe lashed to their seats in order to witness exchanges such as this. Character A: "Did I tell you about my hole-in-one?" Character B: "Only about 17 times." Audience: "Heh, heh, heh." Or, a reference to a traffic policeman as "a trumped-up, little Hitler" receives the sort of murmur of approval that recalls the Dunkirk spirit of endurance against all the odds. The Laugh-O-Gauge needle seldom flickers over halfway. One more line, to cause the mouth to turn up slightly at the edges: "Got to go. Venezuela forest fire!"

That's the trouble with contorted efforts such as Thus My Hero. They try to be wacky, but really continue the terrible tradition of lukewarm comedy set by On the Buses or Are You Being Served? Odd, isn't it, that British creativity gives us Fawlty Towers or Mr Bean at the same time as miserably contrived, derivative and straining-for-effect programs that fill schedules (why the ABC's?) as Wimpy burgers used to pad tummies? That Britain gave the world the Wimpy, along with roast beef and creme-brulee, is another interesting comparison, to which one could add Jamie Oliver and Elizabeth David.

When the most captivating performer is the baby, Ollie, one has to worry. The voice of Ollie receives a separate credit - and well-deserved it is. Actually, Ollie's lip-synching is perfect, and he could well end up with a series of his own - rather like Mr Ed: a horse is a horse, of course of course, and no one can talk to a horse, of course. Alas, in this case, My Hero is Mr Ed from the other end.

urn:contentItem:4CPJ-BDM0-00VK-2356-00000-00<published>2004-06-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>International News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: Aust fires expert warns worst smoke haze yet to come</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Rob Taylor, South East Asia Correspondent</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>JAKARTA, June 24</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Smoke haze from forest fires spreading across Asia from Sumatra was likely to worsen in coming months as illegal burning spread to other parts of Indonesia, an Australian forest fire expert working in the country warned today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The choking haze from wildfires and landclearing is causing havoc in Indonesia, as well as neighbouring Singapore and Malaysia, disrupting flights and causing many motorists to wear masks to avoid smoke-related health problems.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Luca Tacconi, an Australian fire researcher based at the Centre for International Forestry Research in Bogor, south of Jakarta, said the haze - which in some areas was reducing visibility to only a few hundred metres - was likely to get worse in the months ahead.</p><p>"It starts every year in Sumatra, then spreads to parts of west and central Kalimantan as the dry season takes hold across Indonesia," he told AAP.</p><p>"So we are yet to see the peak of the fires, which will come in August."</p><p>Tacconi said the fires were burning out of control in peat land, which was being cleared for oil palm plantations and other crops.</p><p>Once alight, peat is very difficult to extinguish and burns underground for long periods, reaching far into forest areas and exacerbating the fire, smoke and haze problem.</p><p>Singapore has complained to Indonesia about the fires and haze blanketing the island city.</p><p>Malaysia's government said it was considering closing several schools if poor air quality posed a risk to students.</p><p>But Indonesian authorities said they were unable to control the fires and were instead hoping for soaking rain to put them out.</p><p>Ministry of Forestry spokesman Transtoto Handadhari said small farmers were to blame for starting the fires across Sumatra.</p><p>"During the dry season local farmers usually clear the land by using the slash and burn method at the edge of the forests for future cultivation," he told the Jakarta Post.</p><p>"It's a tradition. We can only hope for rain."</p><p>But Tacconi, who has been researching forest fires and the haze problem in Indonesia for three years, said part of the problem was because of poor Indonesian government policy.</p><p>"They need better and more strictly-enforced policy and surveillance," he said.</p><p>"The peat land is valuable and big companies like to clear it for palm oil plantations, which rely on a lot of water.</p><p>"So these companies should be made to pay a higher price for clearing the land, which would help force more responsible clearing."</p><p>Despite the serious 1997-1998 forest fires, which affected 35 million people and drew worldwide attention, haze remains a problem every year for Indonesia.</p><p>That is despite regional countries signing a Regional Haze Agreement in 2002 setting out controls.</p><p>Transtoto did not say whether the farmers or others would face sanctions for defying a government ban on setting fires to clear land.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2004</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4CPJ-BDM0-00VK-2356-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-29</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="474"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2004 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:457Y-SB30-0197-53Y8-00000-00<published>1998-03-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, WORLD; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Air strike combats blazes in Amazon </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A LONG-AWAITED air war against giant fires ravaging the northern Amazon was launched yesterday by Brazilian authorities as high winds pushed flames ever deeper into virgin rain forest.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fire authorities sent two Argentinian helicopters armed with huge water buckets against the fastmoving blazes a day ahead of schedule.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "They're already at work in the area around Apiau, where the situation is most critical," a Roraima State government spokeswoman said. "They were able to equip the helicopters faster than expected."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters, AFP </p></bodyText></section><p>Firefighters from Venezuela have joined hundreds from Brazil and Argentina but despite their efforts a senior conservationist said the area would not recover for 100 years.</p><p> "The fire has turned 100-year-old plants to ash," said Reinaldo Barbosa of the Amazonia Research Institute. "Some slower animals, such as pacas (a rodent), snakes, crocodiles, turtles and armadillos are threatened."</p><p> Those who survive may die of thirst caused by the El Nino-induced drought, Mr Barbosa said. He predicted 50 species of mammals could die of hunger after the fires are extinguished.</p><p> The fires -which began in December -are being fed by the region's worst drought since 1926. Most of the small rivers around Apiau that feed into the Amazon have dried up because of the drought.</p><p> While precise figures are hard to come by, experts agree the flames have cut an immense swath across Roraima, a State roughly the size of Britain. An air survey is under way to get a clearer idea of the extent of the destruction.</p><p> Despite firefighting efforts, the blazes continued to destroy farms, threaten nature reserves and Indian tribes and blanket much of the State with smoke over the weekend.</p><p>Venezuelan civil defence chief Colonel Angel Freites said in Caracas that his country had sent firefighters to Brazil "not just to protect Venezuelan territory but because it is the duty of all Latin American countries to help preserve the lungs of the Earth". Officials had not expected the air assault on the blazes to begin until later this week. But crews were able to outfit the Argentinian choppers quickly with 500-litre water buckets and sent them out on Sunday afternoon.</p><p> The fires are likely to burn until the rainy season begins in the northern Amazon in late April.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4MPM-G740-TX5J-M2XM-00000-00Forest fires a burning issue2006-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisPg. 19Forest fires a burning issueBRUCE FELMINGHAM

TO burn or not to burn? That is the question that must be raised about Tasmania's current forest management strategy in the wake of this devastating fire season.

I believe that 99 per cent of Tasmanians accept the importance of a cohesive fire risk management strategy as part of an overall forest management plan.

We do have a fire risk strategy in place at present, part of which consists of regenerative burns conducted by Forestry Tasmania at the end of the annual fire season.

These controlled burns produce some unpleasant side effects all too evident in the fire haze, which for a brief period in autumn envelopes parts of the island.

Some suggest that regenerative burns should cease forthwith because these have health effects and ultimately harm our tourism industry in the two weeks in March-April when our skies are affected.

This is an overreaction which ignores the forest science. See, for example, N.P. Cheney's Fire Management Issues: RFA Review of Southern Forests Community Group Proposal.

I say overreaction because the alternative environmental consequences of stopping the practice of regeneration burns are much greater than the environmental negatives associated with regenerative burns.

The forest science indicates that the extinction of fires in old-growth forests previously affected by earlier wildfire is extremely difficult in comparison with fires in fire regenerated regrowth forests.

This follows from the fact that old-growth forests retain large quantities of residual timbers from the pre-wildfire forests which, according to NP Cheney's analysis of fire effects above, make fire access and fireline construction expensive and complex.

The old-growth forest fire smoulders for longer periods because of the presence of deep organic soils, which must be penetrated to get at the mineral soils underneath.

Regenerative burns remove much of the debris in a forest, making subsequent fires easier to suppress, thus the greatest potential fire threat can be linked back to the heavy fuel load present in old-growth forests which are not subject to regenerative burning.

Those opposed to this fire risk management practice argue that the consequences of a controlled burn breaking out into an uncontrolled wildfire are so severe that the practice should cease post haste.

However, there is no evidence supporting this view, or none that I can find.

In fact, the major ignition source of Tasmanian wildfire remains arson and more police presence and general surveillance of our forests is the sole solution to this problem.

It seems that the practice of controlled regenerative burning of Tasmania's forests will provide greater environmental and economic benefit than the social costs of the fire and smoke haze evident in some Tasmanian local communities during autumn.

I suspect the great majority can see the common sense of fire hazard reduction.

The environmental damage from the recent fires on Tasmania's East Coast could have been much less severe if hazards had been reduced further.

Forestry Tasmania assesses the commercial value of the forests destroyed on the East Coast at $50 million, while the effects on the natural environment are incalculable.

These escalating fire risks also raise questions about the way in which we manage access to fully reserved forests.

Once these are given fully reserved status, access to them is severely restricted or completely denied. One consequence of this preserved status is that the forests in reserves do not or cannot benefit from a sensible approach to fire hazard reduction.

* Dr Bruce Felmingham is a leading commentator on economics and business.

Pg. 19</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forests facing grave fire risk</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PETER HUNT</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VICTORIA has been hit by a near-record 112 forest fires this year.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Department of Natural Resources and Environment forest fire managers and the CFA are preparing for the worst.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "Normally at the end of September we'd have had just 25 forest fires, but it's hit 112 so far in parks and forests," NRE fire strategist Mike Leonard said.</p><p>"There's only been one other season like it, 1980-81.</p><p> "This has prompted us to prepare early for outbreaks and we're running four to six weeks ahead of normal with those."</p><p> NRE is recruiting 600 to 800 fire fighters and will have 23 fire-fighting planes on stand-by.</p><p> The CFA and State Government are also re-hiring an Erickson Skycrane from the US, a month ahead of schedule.</p><p> The powerful helicopter, nicknamed Elvis, played a crucial role in saving lives and property during the Blue Mountain fires in January.</p><p> The CFA and NRE response has been prompted by reports of dry forests, low streamflows and forecasts of high temperatures until the end of December.</p><p> NRE hydrological reports show more than 60 per cent of the state's streams are flowing at just 10 per cent of their long-term spring average.</p><p> The low stream flows and tinder dry conditions have also prompted CFA concerns about water supplies for fire fighting.</p><p>CFA deputy chief fire officer Craig Lapsley said all brigades had been urged to assess storages to minimise conflicts with town residents and farmers who are already struggling to maintain stock and domestic supplies.</p><p> "We really need to ensure that people have access to water, and we don't want to misuse it," Mr Lapsley said.</p><p> "The advantage we do have is that we can use poorer-quality water and even sea water if necessary, although it does create some problems with equipment.</p><p> "Obviously we will need to constantly reassess these supplies as we move further into the season with less and less water."</p><p> The CFA is also concerned the fire risk will be exacerbated by the latest weather bureau forecast of a 75 per cent chance of higher that average temperatures until at least December.</p><p> Dry fuel loads in the north-west of the state pushed the fire index to 60 out of 100 last weekend.</p><p> The dry conditions have also forced NRE to cut short the usual fuel reduction burns to reduce forest fuel loads.</p><p> Normally, NRE would burn off about 100,000ha over autumn and spring.</p><p> "We had a pretty good autumn with 80,000ha burnt, but only managed to do 1200ha this spring because it got so dry," Mr Lapsley said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3RRM-JNJ0-0048-T2DR-00000-00<published>1998-01-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>US: FEW FIREWORKS FOR AUSSIE DIRECTOR'S FIRST MOVIE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Dale Paget</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> SAN DIEGO, Jan 9 AAP - First time Australian director, Dean Semler, is recovering from scalding reviews for his new movie Firestorm, which opened in the United States today.    Semler, who won an Academy Award as the cinematographer on<br/> Dances with Wolves, is hoping Firestorm will ignite a career as a leading Hollywood director.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The action adventure film, starring former professional gridiron tough guy, Howie Long and actors, Scott Glenn and Suzy Amis, is about a jail escape where the prisoners pose as firefighters while on the run.</p><p>In one of the best reviews for Semler, Los Angeles Times critic, Kevin Thomas wrote that Firestorm works well as a "mindless diversion under cinematographer-turned-director Dean Semler's punchy, efficient helming".</p><p> Thomas added that while the movie was as elementary as action movies come "it moves as fast as the raging forest fire it captures so spectacularly well".</p><p> But other critics were more inclined to toss gallons of water on Semler's first outing as director.    "Unless you're a pyromaniac, latent or practising, there's<br/> little reason to seek out Firestorm," wrote Jay Carr of the Boston Globe. "Perhaps because he comes to directing from cinematography, Semler seems more inclined to concern himself with the look of things than with inscribing character and personality."    The New York Times' Stephen Holden attacked the special effects<br/> complaining that work on the "chintzy looking thriller" suggested that the techniques for filming movie fires "have only gotten sloppier since the burning of Atlanta in Gone With the Wind.</p><p> There was no shelter for Semler in the pages of USA Today.</p><p> "A not-so-towering inferno of action nonsense and overheated mayhem that occasionally entertains in spite of its dopey self," wrote Mike Clark. "You won't feel the burn. But you may feel the heartburn."</p><p> Semler's movie will enter a crowded box office marketplace which has been ruled by the blockbuster Titanic and the latest James Bond film, Tomorrow Never Dies.</p><p> Firestorm star, Howie Long, has had nothing but praise for the Australian director.    "If there is a star that comes out of this film it's Dean<br/> Semler, the director, he is really an incredible man," said Long in a TV interview today.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RRM-JNJ0-0048-T2DR-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="383"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:3S0V-DBB0-0048-T4XN-00000-00<published>1998-02-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDONESIA REPORTS NEARLY 100 BUSH FIRE HOT SPOTS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Lewa Pardomuan</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Feb 12 Reuters - Indonesian officials reported more than 90 "hot spot" areas affected by resurgent bush fires in Sumatra and Borneo island today aggravated by lack of normal monsoon rain.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Smog mainly from fires on Sumatra and Borneo spread across Southeast Asia for weeks last year, setting off health alarms and affecting air, sea and land transportation.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The smog cleared with the arrival of a truncated monsoon season over Indonesia in late October. But the northerly winds that drove the haze away from Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand are only likely to last another six weeks or so.</p><p>An official at the forest fire coordinating bureau in Jakarta said at least 51 hot spots had been recorded on Sumatra and about 40 others in Kalimantan, on the Indonesian side of Borneo island.</p><p> Environmental officials said that if the fires continued to flare and dampened peat bogs were set ablaze again a renewed disaster was in the making.</p><p> "The fires continue in Sumatra and Kalimantan. A lack of rain in those regions worsens the problem," the coordinating bureau official in Jakarta said.</p><p> He said the affected areas in Sumatra included Aceh, North Sumatra, Riau, Jambi and South Sumatra, while in Kalimantan, the eastern part of the region was the most affected areas.</p><p> The number of hot spots had increased significantly from four in Sumatra and 19 in Kalimantan last week.</p><p> All these regions were hard hit by bush fires last year. Many were blamed on peasant farmers and plantation companies burning land to clear it for cultivation.</p><p> Forestry Minister Djamaluddin Suryohadikusumo was quoted by the official Antara news agency as saying this week that satellite photographs had indicated the fires were caused by farmers, adding the ministry had sent an aircraft to help put out the blaze.</p><p> The government earlier said that 265,000 hectares of forests in the archipelago were burnt during the fires of the extended dry season in 1997.</p><p> Forestry officials said this week it appeared two companies were also guilty of setting fires, but they declined to name them until further information was available.</p><p> Some environmentalists have said that due to the current economic crisis, the government was in an even worse position to deal with the problem than it was during the height of the fires last year.</p><p>REUTERS hu</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S0V-DBB0-0048-T4XN-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="394"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P85-1510-TXN5-R1TW-00000-00How 1997 became year the world caught fire1997-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 9How 1997 became year the world caught fireJAMES WOODFORD in Canberra

This year will go down in history as the year that the world burned, losing more than 5 million hectares of forest in massive bushfires unprecedented in modern times, according to a report by the World Wide Fund for Nature.

The head of the forest program at WWF International, Mr Jean-Paul Jeanrenaud, said while the forest fires in Indonesia had grabbed international headlines, "large-scale fires have raged on every continent".

The report says more tropical forest has burnt this year than at any other time in recorded history. Vast areas of forest have been lost in Indonesia, Brazil, Papua New Guinea, Colombia, Peru, Tanzania, Kenya, Rwanda, Congo and other parts of Africa. Fires have also burnt around the Mediterranean, in Russia and China. In recent weeks in NSW around 500,000 hectares of forests were destroyed.

"1997 will be remembered as the year the world caught fire," Mr Jeanrenaud said. "The wide spread of these fires is a clear indication that forest fire management is in a state of crisis."

The report says as much as 2 million hectares was destroyed in Indonesia.

"More than 40,000 Indonesians became ill as a result and smog caused shipping accidents. Primary forest and at least 19 protected areas were damaged, along with endangered species such as the orang-utan . . . Most fires were set deliberately - often illegally - by commercial interests, including plantation owners.

"Impacts were exacerbated by the El Nin~o climatic effect, which was itself probably intensified by pollution-related climate change."

The WWF report also says thousands of square kilometres of grassland and rainforest have been burnt in PNG. "The worst drought for 50 years threatens famine and a massive relief effort is under way; fires add another problem to what is already a desperate situation."

The Professor of Climate Change Studies at the Australian National University, Professor Ian Noble, said some estimates had put the amount of greenhouse gas emissions released by the Indonesian fires as equivalent to up to 1,000 million tonnes - equivalent to a sixth of the emissions from a year of world-wide fossil fuel use.

Illus: A firefighter during the recent NSW bushfires.

urn:contentItem:464J-5S10-015G-Y4T5-00000-00<published>2002-06-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Wildfires besiege Arizona town</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PHOENIX: A huge tract of fire-charred Arizona is expected to be declared a federal disaster area by US President George W. Bush today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Two raging infernos have merged, engulfing more than 121,000ha and driving 25,000 people from their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The monster wildfire bore down on the town of Show Low in the western US state of Arizona yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP</p></bodyText></section><p>"This is the most out-of-control fire I've ever seen," Arizona Governor Jane Hull said after flying over the site.</p><p>"This will be the most expensive fire that anyone has ever seen."</p><p>Fierce flames were creeping into Show Low, which was abandoned by its 8000 residents on Saturday, but a shift in the fire's pattern eased its intensity, saving the town from immediate destruction.</p><p>"The fire has reached the western part of Show Low, but we had some good luck in that its head dissipated and developed into four heads, which slowed the intensity of the blaze," said Cartha Icenhower of the US Forest Service.</p><p>"That has given firefighters a chance to go into the town, douse homes and put out cinders that could spark fires. Even though the fire is burning out of control, there is still hope for Show Low."</p><p>Two huge wildfires burning since last Tuesday joined earlier yesterday to form one mega-fire that has so far scorched 154,400ha.</p><p>Desperate efforts had been under way by about 2000 firefighters, backed by tanker aircraft and helicopters, to prevent the two fires from joining.</p><p>The fires, with flames leaping 150m and igniting huge fireballs, have destroyed 115 homes and sparked the evacuation of six towns, forcing 25,000 from their homes.</p><p>On Saturday, terrified residents packed up trucks and cars after the order to evacuate Show Low in the scenic White Mountains about 290km north-east of Phoenix.</p><p>Most took only the bare essentials, stopping to buy food and water at the stores before fleeing to one of the many school gymnasiums sheltering evacuees.</p><p>Strike teams of fire engines and bulldozers stood by in the town, waiting under a sky so blackened by smoke they could stare directly at the red ball of the sun.</p><p>By yesterday, the town's streets were deserted by all but firemen. White cloths fluttered from the doorknobs of empty houses -- a sign to the firefighters that they had been abandoned.</p><p>Officials said the blaze, fuelled by bone-dry vegetation, high temperatures and winds, was the worst in the history of the forest fire-prone region.</p><p>"The countryside is like a tinderbox and the fires have a life of their own and make their own conditions," said Dorman McGann of the Forest Service, which is co-ordinating efforts to fight the blaze.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3SJJ-45S0-0048-T3S9-00000-00<published>1997-11-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:52:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: THOUSANDS MORE JOBS GO IN INDONESIAN DOWNTURN</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Karen Polglaze, South East Asia Correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Nov 11 AAP - Fifty companies told the Indonesian government they would lay off thousands of workers as the economic crisis and forest fire disaster began to bite into profits.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> These workers would join the 6,000 made redundant by the closure of 16 commercial banks at the beginning of the month in the first official wave of unemployment to follow the decline in the value of the national currency.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> An estimated two million day workers were already out of work as construction sites which had soaked up a steady supply of unskilled labourers ground to a halt due to the El Nino induced drought.</p><p>The Indonesian Association of Contractors (GAPENSI) estimated an additional 500,000 people employed in the property industry were laid off after the business downturn - a result of the drop in the value of the rupiah, which lost more than 35 per cent against the US dollar.</p><p> Manpower Ministry director of work requirements Sahar Sianturi said 50 companies with up to 10,000 workers had notified the department that they planned to make workers redundant. Most had done so in stages, he told The Jakarta Post newspaper.</p><p> "They come from various fields including plywood, sawmill, textile and shoes," Sianturi said. "Most have reached agreements with their workers, including on the question of severance pay."</p><p> Timber companies with operations affected by the fires that have raged out-of-control across parts of Indonesia for months were among those to have laid off workers.</p><p> Some companies had tried to save the jobs by cutting hours, Sianturi said.</p><p> "At least four or five companies have reported decisions to cut working hours or shifts," he said.</p><p> The government had guaranteed bank employees three months' salary after the liquidation of assets of the 16 closed banks.</p><p> The banks closed after the announcement of a $ US23 billion International Monetary Fund plan aimed at shoring up Indonesia in the wake of its multiple disasters.</p><p> The government insisted the closures of the insolvent banks were legitimate despite two legal challenges from banks associated with President Suharto's son businessman Bambang Trihatmodjo and his step brother Probosutedjo.</p><p> Mr Suharto yesterday foreshadowed further steps to strengthen and stabilise the rupiah and to ease liquidity after interest rates were tightened in earlier bids to stem the assault on the currency.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-45S0-0048-T3S9-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="400"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. Pg. 41</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LEARNING FROM ASIAN EXPERIENCE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ED FEATHERSTON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE devastating forest fires that have swept countries to Australia's north this year come as no surprise to Oliver Raymond.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He is fire and harvesting forester for the Amcor Group's Australian Paper Plantations in Gippsland, and has done a lot of consulting work with our northern neighbors.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The work included Indonesia, Borneo, Malaysia and Sumatra, plus Western Samoa in the Pacific.</p><p>"The largest forest fire known to man happened in 1983 in Borneo," Oliver said.</p><p> "It burnt for nine months - and it was an El Nino summer.</p><p> "The El Nino affects them just as much as it affects us.</p><p> "You don't associate tropical forests with fire, and it comes as quite a surprise to some forest investors to find that tropical forests do burn."</p><p> He said 30 per cent of Victoria's fires were started by lightning, but this cause was virtually unheard of in South-East Asian countries.</p><p> Oliver, who has had 32 years with APM Forests, and before that three years with the Forests Commission, heads a team operating 13 firefighting tankers, which form six Country Fire Authority rural fire brigades.</p><p> He said people caused 50 per cent of fires, but sophisticated systems were making it easier to detect, identify and prosecute firebugs.</p><p> Oliver said APM Forests had operated industry brigades for 35 years, working in with the Country Fire Authority.</p><p> The CFA was now pushing formation of these brigades, he said, because of the privatisation of the Victorian Plantations Corporation and implementation of the Commonwealth Government's 2020 Vision program, which aims to see a tripling of the area under forests by the year 2020.</p><p> "Regulations are now being written to cover this.</p><p> "They're trying to write a set of rules for everyone.</p><p> "Its a balance between what is required and commonsense, and they're doing it in consultation with us."</p><p> Oliver said the diesel fire trucks, equipment and fittings used by his brigades were kept simple and compatible with what the CFA used.</p><p> His crews were trained in fires set in selected scrubby areas, with teams sent into action once a strong blaze was under way.</p><p> "I believe if you don't get smoke in your eyes and feel the heat, its not training," he said.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5K91-NVH1-JD34-V305-00000-00'I felt like I was living in a pressure cooker.'2016-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMPg. 4'I felt like I was living in a pressure cooker.'James Blake SINGER, SONGWRITER, PRODUCER, POP WIZARD - INTERVIEWTIM BYRON

London-born singer-songwriter-producer James Blake has a voice you suspect would sound sad singing about sunshine, rainbows and lollipops, and his music has the kind of languid electronics that feel positively icy. His most recent album, The Colour in Anything, had critics using phrases such as "impressionistic melancholy" to describe the album's emotional palette.

Perhaps surprisingly then, Blake comes across as positively upbeat. "I'm in a good place," he says of his current mental state. "It feels a lot easier to wake up every day and look forward to what it brings."

Of course, it doesn't hurt that a lot of big names want to work with him right now. Recently, Blake found himself in Kanye West's studio, as the rapper talked to Madonna on the phone. "I just sat there, not really sure where my life had gone," says Blake, "kind of wondering what they were talking about."

At some point in the conversation, Madonna wanted to talk to him. "It's one of those moments where someone's pointing over to you and you're like, 'me?' and looking around to see if they mean someone else."

So what do you say when Madonna phones Kanye then wants to say hello to you? Blake's answer was perhaps inevitable: "Yeah, hi! Oh, thank you. Uh, OK, bye!"

"It was very sweet," he says. However, he demurs at the suggestion it must be odd to hang out with extroverts such as Kanye and Madonna, as a person who is a bit introverted and self-conscious.

"To be honest, I'm not really. I'm a very social person, and I'm not afraid of anybody. And I'm completely happy to engage on whatever level."

Blake, now 27 years old, was born into a musical family; his father played guitar in 1970s prog rock bands. After finishing school, Blake completed a degree in popular music from Goldsmiths University of London; he even submitted his 2010 Klavierwerke EP as a uni assessment.

He first toured Australia in 2011 after releasing his self-titled debut album. "His single The Wilhelm Scream was the first track we played," says Triple J presenter Linda Marigliano, "and the one that really introduced him to his audience."

In 2011, Blake played Marrickville's intimate Factory Theatre. He won the UK's prestigious Mercury Music Prize in 2013 for his album Overgrown, and now he's playing at the Hordern Pavilion to 10 times as many people.

What's more, Blake's distinctive sound - which Marigliano describes as "true delicacy in his tinkering melodies sitting atop some spectacularly fat bass grooves, [with] organic and electronic elements married together in real harmony" - has had a profound influence on mainstream pop music. Recent No.1 singles such as Zayn's Pillowtalk or Gnash's I Hate You, I Love You would sound quite different without Blake's musical impact. No wonder he ends up at Kanye's studio talking to Madonna.

Yet Blake is dismissive when asked what his distinctive sound means to him. "I think it now means absolutely nothing. As it crops up in other places, it loses its currency. Now, I don't have any intention of adhering to that sound."

Blake's newly found inner peace, seemingly, is not the result of success, but something simpler: letting go.

Until The Colour in Anything, his guiding ethos was do-it-yourself. Between the melodies, the lyrics, the beats, the glitchy electronic sounds, the vocals and the gospel piano, previous records have been all Blake, all the time - he even engineered and mixed the albums himself. However, the pressure of doing it all himself was starting to get to him.

"I just felt like I was living in a pressure cooker, and my head space was getting worse and worse," he says. "I had so many nagging worries when I was making the record ... I felt like I wasn't progressing at the rate I wanted to, and I was kind of in a rut."

He decided to go for a different approach on The Colour in Anything: collaboration. Part of the album was recorded with superstar producer Rick Rubin on the seafront at Malibu, which Blake describes one of the most beautiful places on Earth. They spent the time "just exploring music".

"It really was one of the most defining moments in my life," Blake says.

"It really does absolve you of a lot of pressure when you start to let other people help you."

He is careful, though, to clarify the nature of the help he needed. Most producers make beats and play keyboards, he says. "But I didn't want anyone to get involved that way. I didn't need it. I can do it myself, and I didn't feel like I needed that kind of hands-on help. Which is where Rick came in."

Rubin - the producer behind albums such as Johnny Cash's American Recordings, the Red Hot Chili Peppers' Blood Sugar Sex Majik, and Slayer's Reign in Blood - is the kind of guy who comes across as more of a life coach than a maker of beats.

"What I really needed was guidance," Blake says. Rubin is "really good at mysteriously finding the best in somebody and allowing them to pursue it".

When the guy with the hip, influential sound decides he's open to collaboration, it's no surprise that big names line up to work with him, from Kanye to R&B singers such as Beyonce and Frank Ocean.

Justin Vernon of Bon Iver, who appears on I Need a Forest Fire on The Colour in Anything, tweeted that the song came from "wonderful accidents and good friendship".

Blake also prominently appears on Beyonce's Forward (which he also co-wrote), from her recent album Lemonade. "I didn't consider it something I would have a lot of control over," says Blake of his initial worries about the collaboration. "But in the end, what I did was used with such respect that it gave me a reason to want to go and do it again. I felt really comfortable in that position.

"Despite me using my own lyrics, and despite it not being the most conventional piece of music, she put it on her record, and I think that it really works. I think that they have a good ear, and they got it right."

Blake says he tries not to let preconceptions get in the way of his work. "You know, I don't see people as their avatar. I just respond to what they are in person, and that's the only way you can treat anybody. I think that extends to everybody, from the doorman to the person who owns the venue, to the cleaner, to the band."

For Blake, Kanye West's energy is very positive. "Every time I leave the room after having spoken to him, I'm galvanised and excited. And I can't put my finger on exactly why that is, but I think that's a really fantastic quality."

So Kanye's not the narcissist his public persona suggests?

"He's just a man with a lot of ideas. You know, I think the people around him are panning for gold, but I think that there is

a lot of gold that comes from him ... there's

a reason why he has made so many great albums."

Blake seems fascinated by the nature of celebrity in general. For him, celebrity has positives - "it serves to protect the person themselves, because it puts a distance between them and the rest of the world" - and negatives - "the way people blow out of proportion the importance of somebody and make it very difficult to see the real person underneath it all".

For instance, he says, "You can make hundreds of assumptions about Kanye that don't necessarily ring true."

Blake's openness to new experiences also extends to his live shows. As one of the main drawcards at next weekend's Splendour in the Grass festival in Byron Bay, he promises a good show.

"We know that the support in Australia is fantastic," he says. "I'm not worried about those shows, I think we're going to have a really good time."

James Blake plays Splendour in the Grass on July 24 and the Hordern Pavilion on July 26.

TWO PHOTOS: James Blake at Splendour in the Grass in 2013. He is returning to Australia to play the event again this weekend. PHOTO: RACHEL MURDOLO PHOTO: HAMISH BROWN/CONTOUR BY GETTY IMAGES
