Pg. 33</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NUTRIENTS STUDY IS GOING WITH THE FLOW</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE growth of large blooms of toxic blue-green algae in rivers in recent years has been a problem in many areas of Australia.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> One cause is the over-abundance of nutrients, particularly phosphorus and nitrogen, some of which comes from the discharge of treated sewage effluent.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Not only does this discharge contribute to a major pollution problem, but river disposal of municipal effluent is a waste of a resource that can be used to promote the growth of trees in plantations.</p><p>Each year, towns in the Murray Darling Basin generate sufficient effluent to irrigate up to 25,000ha of fast-growing plantations that otherwise would be unable to survive or produce useable wood products due to low rainfall or lack of nutrients.</p><p> CSIRO soil chemist Randall Falkiner has worked for more than 20 years for the New South Wales Agricultural Department and the CSIRO Division of Forestry and Forest Products on a wide range of soil and plant problems.</p><p> These include soil acidification under leguminous pastures, effects of forest fire on soil chemical properties and nutrient cycling, changes in soil quality and movement of soil P under effluent irrigated plantations.</p><p> Mr Falkiner is one of the speakers who will be featured by CSIRO at the three-day Australian National Field Days at Orange for next Tuesday.</p><p> His present interests include the effect of soil salinity on tree water use and the long-term sustainability of effluent irrigation plantations.</p><p> Recent environmental pressures have required the implementation of methods other than river discharge to treat sewerage effluent.</p><p> Irrigation of tree plantations for wood production has become one of the most popular methods for land-treatment of effluent.</p><p> The area of tree plantations for this purpose has grown to more than 2000ha in the past five years.</p><p> In 1991, CSIRO established the Wagga Wagga Effluent Plantation Project in conjunction with the Wagga Wagga City Council at a site called Flushing Meadows. Its aim was to study the processes of water use, nutrient cycling and salt management in plantations irrigated with effluent and to ensure the treatment can be sustained without causing serious degradation to soil, rivers or groundwater.</p><p> The outcome will be authoritative guidelines to help design, establish and manage sustainable effluent-irrigated plantations under a variety of Australian effluent, soil and climate conditions.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRG0-TXN5-S0H5-00000-00Suharto bans land burn-offs after health concerns1997-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 16Suharto bans land burn-offs after health concernsLOUISE WILLIAMS

Jakarta, Wednesday

President Suharto has banned land-clearing fires as officials revealed 20 million Indonesians are suffering respiratory problems linked to forest fires burning across the country.

The Enviroment Minister, Sarwono Kusumatmadja, said 300,000 hectares of tropical forests on Borneo and Sumatra had been destroyed by run-away fires linked to land-clearing operations using slash and burn methods.

The fires have been exacerbated by a severe drought caused by the El Nino weather pattern. Meteorologists predict an average daytime temperature of 37 degrees across the country this month.

The Government says the fires have been caused by land clearing for plantations, industrial estates and settlements, and by logging companies closely linked to the President.

The smoke has created great pollution with smog affecting health and visibility as far north as Kuala Lumpur.

Mr Sarwono said the President had banned all land-clearing activities and called on 40 of the biggest logging companies to comply.

Environmental activists say the fires are linked to eco-system damage caused by clear-felling. Water from wet season rains is no longer retained in damaged watersheds, leaving shrubs and grasses tinder dry.

Mr Sarwono warned that drought conditions in Indonesia were now worse than in 1982 when fires destroyed two million hectares of forest. He said satellite pictures showed at least 1050 fires were burning, mostly in areas controlled by big companies clearing forests for plantations or industrial estates.

He rejected arguments that nomadic farmers, who traditionally use slash and burn methods, were responsible.

"The bosses of the big planations can just walk into their air-conditioned offices if it gets too smoky, the voiceless people have to take all the blame and suffer from the smoke," Mr Sarwono said.

Two photos: Under a pall: An Indonesian woman carrying buckets of water emerges from the dense smoke of tropical forest fires and waits to cross the main road near Palembang, Sumatra, as a becak, or trishaw, cycles past to be swallowed up in the swirling choking clouds. Pictures: REUTER Two Indonesians examine the blackened path of a forest fire which passed close to the village of Lembak in South Sumatra.

urn:contentItem:4M3S-F1D0-TXDB-C23F-00000-00Fire patterns change as Australian summers get hotter2006-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisThe World Today12:22 PM AESTABCChris UhlmannFire patterns change as Australian summers get hotter

PETER CAVE: Usually fires in Australia follow a predictable pattern. They first appear in the northern states early in the season and then they migrate south as the summer wears on. This season though, it's been different.

The NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Phil Koperberg spoke to Chris Uhlmann and began by listing Australia's most devastating fires.

PHIL KOPERBERG: Ash Wednesday of 1983, South Australia and Victoria, Hobart in 1967 were all events which basically took place in the latter part of what would be a traditional Australian summer season.

Whereas, in the early part as early as August perhaps, or certainly September, you'd see a lot of fire activity in places like south-east Queensland and north-east New South Wales and in fact, right along the Queensland, New South Wales border.

So for the first time that I can remember, and I've been in this business for 40 years, we're seeing the exact opposite happen.

It is virtually unheard of to have fires in the Kosciusko and the Snowy Mountains this time of year. You'd expect those in late December, early January, maybe even February.

And yet our predominant problems are emerging there. The least of our problems appears to be the north-east.

So it is a spectacularly unusual event.

CHRIS UHLMANN: How worried should we be?

PHIL KOPERBERG: Well, I keep being asked what sort of a fire season it's going to be and I can only predicate my response upon what meteorologists tell me, and if I predicate my response to you on that, then I'd have to say we're in for a tough time and if this is an indicator of years to come, we need to change our view on what constitutes a typical Australian fire season.

Yesterday, Hobart had a forest fire danger index of well over 100. Now, they've never had that before in October.

CHRIS UHLMANN: Are we seeing - because that fire index of 100 of course, was developed after the Second World War, which was the most extreme day that you could possibly experience - are we seeing more of those kinds of days in Australia?

PHIL KOPERBERG: Yes, we are. Today will be our third successive day of extreme weather somewhere in the state, and by extreme weather, I simply mean weather which will generate a fire danger index in excess of 50.

And that fire danger index, as you know, is a logarithmic scale of zero to 100, based on drought factor, on fuel curing, temperatures, humidity or dew point and wind velocity.

Tomorrow we'll see our fourth or fifth successive day. Sunday will see our sixth successive day where somewhere in the state we have a total fire ban because of that high index.

And I don't remember that happening before. I remember lots of days, when over the whole of the state would be under the influence of that sort of weather or part of it, but not four or five successive days in October.

PETER CAVE: New South Wales Rural Fire Services Commissioner Phil Koperberg.

urn:contentItem:5D2S-KM61-JCBD-B341-00000-00Ten books that have stayed with me through my life2014-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:52:33ZLexisNexisAPg. B003Ten books that have stayed with me through my lifeThe Canberra Times

Ten books that have stayed with me through my life I usually don't partake in Facebook challenges.

I'm not interested in finding out which Disney Princess I am, nor what city I should live in. I'm no princess and Canberra suits me just fine for the moment, thank you very much.

But I'm going through a bit of a books phase, reading one good book (see The Bees, below) will do that, reignite a love that you've neglected for a while. Part of my spring promise to myself was to read for half an hour every night before I go to sleep, and I've managed that for the best part of this week. I found a great quote - yes, on Facebook - from author Anna Quindlen: "We read in bed because reading is halfway between life and dreaming" and I've adopted it as something of a mantra.

So when my dear friend Shannon threw up the challenge of listing 10 books that had "stayed with you in some way" I readily accepted it.

"They don't have to be the 'right' books or great works of literature, just ones that have affected you in some way," she said.

Here we go.

1. Centennial, by James A. Michener (1974) This is the book that convinced me I wanted to be a writer. Centennial traces the history of the state of Colorado, weaving fact with fiction from prehistory to the early 1970s.

Michener's ability to tell a story is unmatched, in detail and drama, and that's what I wanted to do, tell stories. The people of Colorado were dreamers, and I hope there's a little bit of them in me too.

2. Prince of Tides, by Pat Conroy (1986) I'm pretty sure I didn't read this book until after I'd seen the 1991 film version starring Barbra Streisand and Nick Nolte. The film, which was nominated for the Best Picture Oscar, is about a family who suffers through unimaginable tragedy. It moved me; the book even more so.

Conroy's writing is lyrical and poetic and transformative. Reading Prince of Tides was like immersing yourself in water, calming and comforting, but with an undercurrent of danger at every breath.

3. When I Grow Up, A Little Golden Book (1968) My mother would return from the grocery shopping each week with A Little Golden Book. I had quite the collection and still have a few tucked away for my childrens' children.

Favourites included Doctor Dan: The bandage man; My Dolly and Me; We Help Mommy; Good Little, Bad Little Girl ... but my all-time favourite was When I Grow Up (pictured). Yes it was stereotyped and sexist and totally inappropriate in many ways but this little girl grew up believing she could sell ice cream on the moon.

4. The Bees, by Laline Paull (2014) I credit this book (pictured) with getting me reading again. Paull takes a fat, ugly bee and turns her into a heroine for our time. Flora 717 captured my heart as she fought for her rightful place in the hive, her right as a mother, her right as a woman (OK, female bee). Halfway between Animal Farm and The Handmaid's Tale (both books close to this list) this is a book that will change the way you think about everything. I sobbed uncontrollably at the end of The Bees, one because I had finished it and two because I was left with a feeling of not knowing what to read next because nothing could match it.

5. One Day, by David Nicholls (2009) The book was a love story for the ages, the book a decent enough rom- com. We catch up with Emma and Dexter on July 15, every year through 20 years, from university to middle age. I've just begun Us, Nicholls' latest offering and I'm not sure I'm game to keep reading. This book is about the years after 40 and I'm scared it might all be a little too close to home.

6. The Day of the Triffids, by John Wyndham (1951) Now here's a scary arse book. I think I read this at university, going through a phase where I felt I needed to have some "classic" on the go.

Imagine it. Carnivorous plants taking control of the world. Add in that everyone else is blind, or crazy, or both, and no wonder a generation or two grew up with a mistrust of houseplants. Made us all think about whether or not we'd survive a post- apocalyptic event. Not sure I would.

7. Nancy Drew series (1930-2003) Nancy Drew, girl detective, role model, best friend, life wasn't complete unless you were helping Nancy (or sometimes Trixie Belden) solve a mystery. Among my favourites were The Mystery of the Moss-Covered Mansion, The Quest of the Missing Map and The Message in the Hollow Oak. I remember the Moss Covered Mansion pretty well, hard to forget seeing it involved a truck load of explosive oranges, the space movement, gypsies and a forest fire. And I even grew up and married one of the Hardy boys.

8. Baby Love, by Robin Barker (1994) This book was my bible when my own two children were babies. The now dog-eared book lived next to the cot, giving me reassurance at arms length. Baby Love is full of commonsense advice and well-documented research, all delivered with the firm guidance of a knowledgeable aunt.

9. Great Expectations, by Charles Dickens (1860) If your favourite HSC text doesn't stick with you what would? Either this, or Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness or Shakespeare's King Lear, all from the class of 1984. Here Pip and Estella and Joe team up with Miss Havisham and Abel Magwitch and how could you forget the delightfully named Mr Pumblechook?

10. Bel Canto, by Ann Patchett (2001) A group of terrorists take hostages at a birthday party. Another lyrical book of great intensity but one that touches the heart of human emotion and our need to be wanted.

What's on your list? @karenhardyCT #10books
